COMMENTS: \I feel scared biking on the \"\"green carpet\"\" bike lane here because the intersection is so wide open. I feel like a speeding car could peel off from Comm Ave onto Bay State and clip me.\""

While I love that the Comm Ave bike lane is to the left of the road and not next to the parked cars (not in door zone), it's very difficult to cut over 3-4 lanes at Charlesgate East to continue on the bike lane which switches to the right side here.
Need a bike facility to connect Boylston St to Park Plaza/Columbus Ave. Current one way street grid here makes cyclists ride in a huge loop down to Stuart St.
3 lane, no parking either side. SPEEDWAY. No separation from sidewalk. I'm scared with speeding cars only a couple feet from me.
People who are walking constantly run the red light here, which makes it very dangerous for themselves and others.
The SWC path has an outlet here right across from Stony Brook Station but there's no crosswalk.
People driving out of the rotary and going onto Day St often don't yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk across Day St.
\An \"\"except bikes\"\" under the Do Not Enter sign on Barbara St at S Huntington would be helpful so that Hubway users can get to the station easier.\""

Where is the southwest corridor bike path through here? It's supposedly on the sidewalk, but the parking garage and insane amount of pedestrians make it unusable. I often have to ride in the street here until the bike lane on Columbus Ave begins.
Hemenway from Boylston to Westland is one way, but it's super wide. Can we get a two way cycle track?
Huge wide open intersection
Cars from Storrow Drive don't yield when turning onto Arlington St.
Always traffic here. Remove one of the parking lanes full time!

It feels like it will take forever to get from the far side of Brookline ave to the far side of Boylston St. I should be able to cross these two streets in one go. I shouldn't have to stand on the island and wait another whole light cycle!

You think they're going to stop but they usually coast. I think people have gotten used to the fact that both streets lead away from this intersection, so unless there is someone trying to cross, then there's no reason to stop.
The street is one lane in each direction with parking only on one side, yet it is at least 60ft wide. What gives?
Super wide intersection for a relatively minor side street. Tighten it up!
The corners are so far set back that it's difficult for cars to see you waiting to cross. As a result, they don't stop for you.
The geometry of this intersection makes visibility hard. The new one way on E First St helped a little, but there's a lot more that can be done, including hopefully a crosswalk.
the hotel valet always has cars double parked in this area, and it's very dangerous for cyclists!
it's very scary to walk through the intersection because the cars do not slow down while turning.
It takes a really long time to be able to cross the street, which is especially frustrating during the summer months when there are a lot of tourists.
There is always double parking on both sides of the street for the coffee shops, yoga studio, etc. It's dangerous and annoying when I bike, drive, or bus.

An old woman tried to cross a parking lane, 2 travel lanes, 2 trolley tracks, and then 2 more travel lanes from The Mission towards the Santander. Her  carriage kept getting stuck on the tracks and I feared a turning vehicle would wipe her out!
There's a statue that's a tourist attraction, a bus stop, and this is a good location to take picture of the State House. There's no room for people to safely stand!
The divider island has sunk into the ground and there's poor signage about the left lane needing to turn left onto S Huntington. Cars always crash into the median and take out the signs.

Due to the length of the buses and the narrow street, they frequently run up on the sidewalk while turning. If you (the person walking) aren't careful you run the risk of being run over while being ON THE SIDEWALK.
There are constantly cars running the lights at this intersection.
\The length of Tremont from E Berkeley all the way into Roxbury near Melnea Cass. \"\"Just need to stop for a second to run into the packie! Who cares if I'm in the way!?!\"\"\""
Papa John's and Hollywood Liquors
No sidewalks or even a path along this road and this is through a park!
People drive like they're in a road race. The physical landscape seems to support this behavior.
snow on the bike lanes make it really dangerous for bikers.
the road is extremely bumpy and uneven. There is almost no paint on the ground, which makes this area a free for all.
Crossing Chestnut Hill and then Comm Ave according to the WALK signs takes 2 full cycles. It means I miss the train or have to stand in rain or snow for a long time.

the roadway is super wide here with no lane markings so it's confusing where to ride and cars go super fast. Lots of trucks around here too. It's frightening, but the only way to go to get back to Mass Ave westbound.

As someone who walks from SE of the intersection, I have to make multiple crossings to get to the T station. It's obvious from experience that I can safely cross at times when it says not to walk. Update the signals.

I'm one of those people. Many people walk north through the park and parking lot and want to cross directly to where a set of stairs have been installed for people to walk to the stores. Please add a crosswalk to make this midblock safer.
People do not understand which lane to move into when taking a left from Arlington onto Boylston.

I rarely use the crosswalk because the light holds the drivers back & if I take the time to walk to the crosswalk I'll have to wait another light cycle. There should be another crosswalk here to take people to the island.
Traffic turning onto Ashmont from Newhall have a blind turn, needs signage.
No safe way to get out of South Boston to the west.
People don't stop for pedestrians in the crosswalk.
People often give up and cross without waiting for the ped light.
Climbing up Beacon Street is really uncomfortable for people who aren't very fit and comfortable holding the lane vs tour buses.
There's a crosswalk, but there's no traffic signal or stop sign so cars do not yield as they drive down Park Plaza road
Cars do not stop at the crosswalk.
Should be another crosswalk for those heading to T station. Too difficult to see around curve in both directions to cross safely. Also people drive extremely fast on this street.
Cars coming down Pleasant St. (a wide street) at full speed accelerate to make the Columbia Rd. light, as they enter narrower, kid-heavy Pond St. at E. Cottage and Edison Green.

Lots of people cross here from the monument to the museum and people speed down this street ignoring the crosswalk. I've also seen drivers watch one side of the street and ignore the other when negotiating the crosswalk.

It's dangerous crossing Lindsey Street at the top of the street because drivers speed while making the turn from Greenbrier into Lindsey.When I've requested a stop sign, I have been told they can't put one in because it's not an intersection.
There isn't much vehicular traffic crossing here so people go relatively fast and don't check the cross street for the people walking and running up the hill who seem to appear out of nowhere.
People speed and incredibly dangerous to bike on without a bike lane or markings of any kind.  No need for 3 lanes of traffic here.
Inadequate pedestrian/bicycle separation from traffic. Poor lighting, feels unsafe at night. Intersection is sometimes blocked with traffic, making crossing even more unsafe.
Inadequate pedestrian/bicycle separation from traffic. Poor lighting, feels unsafe at night. Intersection is sometimes blocked with traffic, making crossing even more unsafe.

The slip lane encourages people to treat the turn lane onto Chelsea Street like a highway on-ramp. Except for the moment when the light turns to red, people drive through the right turning movement without slowing down (even when the light is red).

The N. Wash. Bridge desperately needs bike lanes. The scariest is here where cars turning right make crazy maneuvers instead of just staying to the right. When I bike, I usually go straight and there's almost no way to do this safely.
Traffic moves too fast on Congress Street, particularly east on Congress towards PO Square.

There is never a back-up on the N. Washington Bridge and it's amazing how fast people go. There are so many people who use the sidewalk on this side that I try to use the road, but the way people accelerate is crazy.

Many people use St James Street as a throughway while walking/driving... nearest crosswalk is quite far. Many pedestrians cross haphazardly across Washington St which has fast traffic. Unsafe for ped and drivers. Multiple accidents here.
This street is very narrow and on a one-way downhill but there's no winter parking ban. This creates a very dangerous situation in the snowy season and many parked cars have been hit.
Very high traffic pedestrian area (and increasing). Walk signal takes very long, and results in many pedestrians dashing across 4 busy lanes of traffic on Washington street.
Very busy bike path merges with pedestrian way, would help to have marked bike lanes to keep pedestrians alert of oncoming bikers.

Drivers merge at very high speeds into the far left lane on Beacon street in order to turn left onto Arlington Street. They do not yield for bikers already in the left lane, and merge at very high speed.

Cyclists who turn right from Charles St onto Beacon and intend to turn left onto Arlington have to contend with merging traffic and high speeds when crossing multiple lanes in order to get to the far left lane for the turn onto Arlington.
People double park here at the corner, which forces drivers going up the hill to cross into the oncoming lane where drivers going down the hill cannot see them.
Construction vehicles for the Longfellow Bridge repair block access from the bike lane (i.e., turning right from the bridge) onto Charles Street.

This intersection would greatly benefit from a stop light. Centre street is very busy and people tend to drive very fast. It's also where a lot of cars are entering onto or exiting off of Centre Street into/out of Roslindale/Arboretum.

The street is too narrow, it allows parking on one side and its a two way street.  When your turning the corner from Chestnut Square to Glendale Ter, you cannot see a car coming up or down, and if cars are parked can cause a head on collision.
narrow street with narrow sidewalks right against the road. speeding cars pass within 3ft of walkers
This street needs speed bumps due to cars avoiding traffic on Washington St. and driving excessively fast down a residential street.
the Tremont Street traffic primarily in the AM
No sidewalk ramp
need a cycletrack
Beacon street should have a dedicated bike lane. It's wide enough and a major route for bikes.
There are no sidewalks on this street, and it is busy because it is one of the few entrances to Ross Playground.
Funky traffic pattern, between service road and comm ave westbound, confusion in terms of cars taking rights yielding to service road.
It's very hard to see the oncoming traffic and there's lots to worry about right here, because you're also crossing train tracks.
Very hard to see oncoming traffic and watch out for trains at same time. Very dangerous cross-through.

Cars park on both sides of Train Street and one side of Victory Road. Both streets are two-way streets, so it becomes very difficult to navigate when there are vehicles attempting to turn either onto Victory from Train or onto Train from Victory
There is NO crosswalk here. I requested one be installed almost a year ago, to no avail. Area is unsafe to cross. Cars park very close to the corners, thus making crossing safely impossible.

Vehicles are often parked (illegally?) on the NE corner of the intersection of Congress & Farnsworth (in front of Boston Fire Museum), making it difficult to see westbound traffic on Congress while entering from Farnsworth
The road is very narrow--not enough room for two-way traffic. It should either become a one-way street, or parking should be only on one side.
This intersection seems really dangerous because the wait is so long for a walk signal. Most people just jaywalk.

Buffered bike lane along curb -- people use this wide space to park illegally or as an added travel lane. Some sort of barrier, even cheap, removable bollards, would be an improvement and prevent people from violating this space.
All along Green from Washiington to Centre.
Very often several cars will run this red light as I am crossing Comm Ave on my way to work
The intersection with mass is always dicey and there are constantly trucks and cars double parked here, blocking the bike lane and forcing me into traffic.
despite signs, cars rarely yield to pedestrians at these crossings.  particularly challenging if one car stops for you but cars keep passing it in the other lane
High traffic road with many potholes

At D street and west  first street lights driving towards the Seaport roadway marking better so right lane must turn right because at the light in the left lane you have to merge to the right to go straight and cross west first street.

Pedestrians trying to walk east on the northern side of Comm Ave wait for 2 diff walk signals. 1st when crossing Essex/Mountfort/BU Bridge from west to east then just to cross the access lane for cars to get on bridge.
Drivers in the Left turn only lane will go straight and cause accidents with drivers in the adjacent lane who also go straight in the same lane
Cars drive extremely fast on the carriageway between Colborne and Leamington, which is a hill and makes it hard to see pedestrians and double-parked cars at such high speeds.

We need a connection from the EB greenway to the chelsea creek watefront - e.g. condor street. If I'm tryng to get to Chelsea or beyond, I go from fantastic infrastructure to one of the hardest intersections to cross.
No one stops at this stop sign. It is very hard to see over parked cars, especially since drivers come up and over a hill just before the intersection.
No one stops at this stop sign. It is very hard to see over parked cars, especially since drivers are coming down a hill.

almost everyone who parks on the west side of adamds south of ashmont parks on the sidewalk and obstructs nearly half of the walking space. i have nearly been hit multiple times by people pulling up and over the curb.
Two Crosswalks are needed at the park near Moreland St. Moreland is the only two way street for several blocks and gets all the traffic.  Crosswalks would help children and adults cross to the park
dangerous to cross tracks and see around the corner.

People visiting the Ba Le double park all day 7 days a week with the problem growing exponentially during the weekends. Cars block the travel lanes, bike lanes, and often will live park blocking both Hallam and St Williams streets.
You have to delay when the light turns green at Moreland and Warren because of all the Warren St. drivers running the light.

This is an important crossing for pedestrians who live across the train tracks from Roslindale Square. The traffic light has a pedestrian light but drivers often run the red light when turning from South St. onto Belgrade Ave.
As soon as the walk light is on, cars want to turn into you and it's dangerous to cross Mass Ave!

This stretch is so bad I bike less b/c of it. Sharrows do not work here. No good alt routes from Coolidge corner area to downtown. Cycletracks would b nice. Does traffic volume really warrant 2 lanes in both directions? Bike safety before parking.

This is a completely logical place for pedestrians to cross Belgrade Ave, but there is no crosswalk. Perhaps a crosswalk could be added and a pedestrian signal that is coordinated with the signal at South St and Belgrade Ave.

\Not enough time to cross 4 lanes and a median going straight up Washington across Kneeland Street - crosswalk begins blinking \"\"Don't Walk\"\" before I reach median. This area has a lot of tourists"

\Pedestrians are signaled to \"\"walk\"\" at the same time traffic is signaled to \"\"turn left\"\" on Huntington Ave from Belvediere St as well as traffic turning right from West Newton Street onto Huntington Ave.\""
Drivers cutting through Savin Hill fly over the bridge and down toward Dorchester ave. A raised crosswalk would force drivers to slow and improve safety for pedestrians.
Movie theater.  All  the    time.
Does there really need to be 2 lanes of traffic in both directions on this bridge? Seems like a relic of the 1950s highway era. I hardly see much traffic even during rush hour.
This intersection is huge and unless you are right up at the front of traffic its hard to go Westbound from Brighton Avenue to Cambridge Street

Parents double park and make U-turns.  Teachers,too.  These are visitors dropping off their kids. BPS needs a literature campaign about safe drop offs New traffic light and B2 police detail are good though !

Many issues here. Outbound drivers making a right onto Mountfort do not yield to bikes; bike lane ends right where drivers are speeding downhill; cars crossing from Maitland to Mountford should not be allowed.
Crosswalk needs improvement now with more car & ped traffic due to new Whole Foods - I push button, wait for crosswalk, never comes, so I cross on my own despite cars speeding up to highway ramps
There is also too long of a wait and loo many legs to cross at once.
Having to cross two lanes of speeding traffic to access to the left side bike lane is TERRIFYING and dangerous. It doesn't work for anyone--drivers and bicyclists alike.
the hotel is a terrible offender. livery vehicles completely disregard the bike lane - even when the paint is visible (it was eradicated last winter by plow scraping)
Let's revive the public garden cycle track idea! But at the very least, we need some kind of inbound bike lane on Boylston.

the intersection is completely uncontrolled - no stop sign, no yield sign, no signal. we need something here for the safety of all modes. if there is a control device, it is not clear at all who has the right of way.
Following the removal of this crosswalk across New Washington Street due to Arborway construction pedestrians continue to cross here and put themselves in danger.  Why has this not been replaced?
The road is too way, but is far too narrow.
Valet vehicles always take up space, despite the fact that this might be the largest valet zone in the City!
This isn't a loading dock. Huge trucks shouldn't be backing in up against the curb blocking both travel lanes and having people squeeze by in the parking lane.
There was talk of a cycle track on Westland Ave after it was repaved, but this has not yet materialized. Let's make it happen :)
The pavement conditions in this stretch of mass Ave are especially dangerous, especially in the marked bicycle lane

Everyone knows and says this intersection is just a disaster to drive or walk in. Hold a retreat somewhere out in the woods and come up with a way to fix it. It just doesn't work, especially for pedestrians.

The crosswalk extends too far into the intersection, and cars turning left from Essex onto Lincoln get a green when pedestrians get a walk light. Itâ€™s too easy for cars to turn into pedestrians at high speed. A friend and I were seriously injured.

Walking through Liberty Sq on Water St is all kinds of scary! Northbound drivers speed around the bend on Kilby Street, and visibility is limited by parked cars. Traffic seems to come from all directions!
4.5 lane wide driveway for stop and shop? I feel so exposed crossing here. It should be converted to a regular curb cut. This isn't a high capacity roadway, it's a parking lot..
Considering Cambridge St is one of the busiest bicycle corridors in Boston (on account of the bridge), it's crazy that there are no bicycle facilities.
Would be great to paint some bike lanes--or better yet a cycle track--directing bicyclists to the footbridge at the end of Blossom St for access to the riverside bike path.

People park too close to the intersection and it is very dangerous to turn out of the road. I nearly get into an accident turning almost every single day. People go very fast on Forest Hills so it makes it very difficult.
I see more red light running in this intersection than any other I visit daily.

People park too close to the intersection and it is very dangerous to turn out of the road. I nearly get into an accident turning almost every single day. People go very fast on Forest Hills so it makes it very difficult.
Sidewalk here and across the street is never shoveled in the winter. A lot of people walk down Washington Street to Dudley Station and end up walking in the street if there's snow on the ground.
\Stop sign on Warren Ave at W. Canton is very hard to see
column7: and frankly
column8: it's unexpected here.  Many cars miss it
column9: I believe as an honest mistake. Maybe it should be 'Yield\"\"?\""

COMMENTS: People constantly run this stop sign. They slow down, but rarely stop.
There needs to be a timer on when people can cross.
Drivers frequently fail to yield to pedestrians crossing in the crosswalk.

The off street mixed-use path that runs along Seaver St is un-plowed and icy. Car traffic on Seaver St is too fast and busy, so this path is necessary to be able to get around the park on the north side.

Drivers frequently fail to stop at the stop signs at this intersection, which also contains two crosswalks.  I have come close to being hit several times by drivers who blow through this intersection.
Cabs and cars speed through this street, many time at dangerous speeds.

There is no ped-cross signal and there is a mix of stop signs and stop lights. Cars and pedestrians do not work together here, and the result is usually a blocked intersection, little traffic movement, and general disarray.
Due to the curve of Dorchester Ave, and the cars parked on the corner, there is no visibility when leaving Romsey to turn on to Dorchester Ave.

I live on this corner. The signs only indicate that the right of the three lanes will turn right onto Beacon, but the accepted practice is for both the right and middle lane to turn into the two lanes on Beacon, and cars collide 1-2 times a day here.
There is no stop sign for the cars driving down Daly Street. A 4 way stop sign is needed at this intersection.
Massive potholes on ramp from Beacon / Charlesgate area to Storrow Dr. West
There is no stop sign on Rosemont where it intersects at Adams. A stop sign is needed here.
Evening rush hour is a fiesta of red-light running as cars go south from L.Prang to Ruggles.  Regularly blocks eastbound Huntington and the Green Line.
Everyone crosses in the middle it's a very dangerous intersection.

The left turn from Essex to Atlantic is very dangerous. The bike lane goes from right, to middle. Cars planning a right turn onto Summer St will ALWAYS cross the flow of bike traffic. Bike lanes should connect, without having car traffic crossing.

This is a three way road with people coming off a bridge or going onto the Bridge. During rush hour it is very unsafe with cars cutting off people with the right of way. there are also many predestrians that walk in the area including students.
Due to the curve of Adams Street, visibility when turning is very low if cars are parked in front of 473 Adams St. Parking needs to be eliminated in front of 473 Adams St.
Drivers routinely drive the wrong way down Fox Street to turn on to Juliette. Area needs enforcement.
The roadway here is a disaster.  The entire right lane has so many patches manholes and potholes, that keeping a bike upright, while avoiding getting doored by the cabs is a daily adventure.
Drivers routinely run the stop signs at this intersection.
There needs to be a 4 way stop sign here.
the cars are racing to get to the expressway and don't stop
Auto body shop takes up too many parking spots on this narrow stretch of road.
Drivers on Dorchester Ave routinely block the box at the Lincoln St intersection causing drivers to miss the light.
Drivers routinely run the red light from Blue Hill Ave to American Legion Highway.
Difficult intersection to cross on bike/walking, even though it's a main artery from South Dorchester to Downtown/Seaport. Morrissey in general could better serve Neponset residents who don't drive.
Especially when pedestrians have the walk signal.
I've witnessed 2 car accidents due to people not understanding what lanes are OK for turning onto Summer St.-better signage needs to be put up that allows cars to be in the correct lanes.
The corner lot fence is too high to see around the corner
I've had close calls as people make a right turn in front of me as I have a walk signal. Can you add a sign that says no turns during pedestrian crossing
Street is too narrow for 2 cars to pass. Parking should be eliminated or road made one way.
3-way ppl need to yield to one another -- also ppl are trying to cross the street

Crossing Beacon St northward from Reservoir station to the other side of Cleveland Circle is an intimidating undertaking to say the least. Crossing with the signals can take several minutes, at least.
Street is too narrow for 2 cars to pass on the entire length of Centre Street. Street needs to be made one way or parking eliminated on one side of the street.
PLEASE make a ped bridge across the harbor! Would love to have the option to walk/run/bike to work downtown.
Ppl don't stop at the stop sign or yield
The right on red can become a dangerous free for all at South St/Comm Ave
Frequently cars run the red light while driving on West Roxbury Parkway.  Drivers on Weld St have to look both ways when the light turns green
Pedestrians don't yield to motor vehicles when they have a don't walk signal.
Drivers routinely travel the wrong direction on one-way Antwerp St.

the brick sidewalk from The Atlantic Beer Garden to the concert venue, is uneven, and theres steps in the middle which causes a person in a wheelchair to have to make a quick decision to go to the paved sidewalk and weave between walking pedestrians

MBTA buses turning left from Franklin to Devonshire (towards Winthrop Square) ROUTINELY ignore the pedestrian walk sign and plow through this intersection, even when pedestrians are in the crosswalk with a walk signal.
Cars use Brown Ave as a cut through street and speed down this section frequently.  It is a school zone with a park that is frequented used by kids that cross the street in this area.
The waiting area for pedestrians to cross Park St from the Common is incredibly small and feels dangerous with turning traffic from behind.
Cars turn right on red when walkers have a walk symbol.
Crossing the street here in the crosswalk is a deathwish, Cars speed around a blind corner here and rarely yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk.  Traffic enforcement needed.
This stretch of Summer/Winter is mostly pedestrian only, but is used too often by regular vehicles without consequence. Make these streets pedestrian only!
Cars frequently blow through stop signs in all directions here.

A crosswalk with a bump-out at Beacon and Somerset could vastly improve pedestrian safety. Many people cross this section of Beacon (bet. Somerset and Tremont) away from crosswalks as there are none in the area. Visibility is poor due to parked cars.

Parents of students at Edward Brooke school frequently ignore all parking rules on Brown Ave, blocking driveways, fire hydrants and ignoring no parking signs.  They also block traffic and let their kids out in the middle of the street.
\Ha ha. The concrete ramp at the light crossing Stuart (near bank
column7: heading towards Starbucks) Ramp is so steep that I've seen several people \"\"ski\"\" down it and fall in or near the street.\""

COMMENTS: Drivers fly over the hill ignoring stop sign and zoom down hill. Numerous cars have crashed into corner house 159 Trenton Street. School is close by and the kids are in danger here. Speed bump recommended between Putnam and Trenton.
there is no crosswalk at the intersection of Harvard and Brainerd rd. people cross here all the time against traffic and it is very dangerous.

This is a fairy busy intersection with cars cutting through from Huntington Ave corridor to go towards Ruggles and Melnea Cass. It is very hard to see when taking a left onto Parker Street from Ward Street.
Couldn't this be changed to a concurrent walk signal?
longwood avenue is heavily used in both directions by cycle commuters. bike lanes do not exist but they are very necessary to make a busy road safer!
The crossing between the Park Plaza and Lincoln Sq (and vice versa) is much wider than seems necessary and often results in drivers not yielding on turns.
Test
\A ton of commuters pour off buses and the T right here
column7: and many of them end up crossing the street before the \"\"walk\"\" signal. Can we time \"\"walk\"\" signals to coincide with trains arriving?\""

COMMENTS: Parking rules limiting parking close to intersection are not enforced, making it difficult to turn onto Elm Street, and limiting visibility of pedestrians.

The walk signal across Blossom St is too short, and there is much too long of a wait for it.  Moreover, the button has to be pushed to get a signal--this is pointless since there are always pedestrians waiting, and many people don't realize this.

Cars routinely double park or park illegally (too close to the intersection), completely eliminating visibility for cars turning onto Bunker Hill Street from Elm Street. These cars typically belong to, or are visiting, Carr Funeral Home.
This is one of the worst intersections in the city.  Cars and pedestrians both ignore the signals, and cars speed through red lights.
The bike lane going straight towards Oliver Street goes through the turn onto 93 and lots of drivers dont bother to see if people are going straight before turning
It's dangerous for bikes heading west on Beacon. Bike's need to cross fast moving right hand turning vehicles in order to the straight-only lane.
Massport + taxis + valet double-park in the bike lane all along this road
On this one-lane intersection of Sullivan Square, people us the bike lane/shoulder as a turning lane.
Cars often create a second lane of traffic in the shoulder/bike line.

There is a do not enter sign on Aramon St, which makes half of the street a one way street. However, cars regularly disobey the sign and drive the wrong way.  Please police as this has nearly caused head on accidents.

People regularly park in the bike lane northbound and southbound.  Moving around the double parkers is dangerous because drivers are aggressive and there are larger vehicles that I have to dodge because they assume I will stay in the bike lane
The right lane is used for double parking while people pick up food nearly every evening.
Dangerous Intersection. Need signal

Crosswalk missing at an intersection also a built entry point of a MAJOR pedestrian transit hub (Charles River crossing AND commuter station.  There are crosswalks at EVERY OTHER intersection to the west!

Now that this bridge is closed I bike over the channel on streets that FEEL less safe than this one.  Please restore / rebuild this bridge for exclusive pedestrian & cyclist use. (and emergency vehicles during emergencies if need be)
Crossing Mass Ave at Newbury is very scary. Cars don't yield as they turn onto the Pike.

Crosswalk missing at intersection and connection between major pedestrian destinations: North End/Rose Kennedy Greenway and Charles River crossing AND commuter station.  Crosswalks at EVERY OTHER intersection to the west but the NEAREST TWO!
No sidewalk and street markings where the bike path meets foot traffic from Ruggles and campus. Painted path on sidewalk would be ideal so bikes can follow and peds can be aware

Signal timing causes accidents. WB signal turns red while EB signal is still green. WB cars turn left (South) at the end of the WB yellow not realizing the EB signal is green and get hit by EB cars. Please add red L-turn signal at end of WB green.
This road needs to have separated bike lanes.
Cars consistantly turn right on red here, despite the signage.

When riding a bike southbound on Washington, the bike lane drops as you approach Haymarket and the street section widens to four lanes.  I've started diverting all the way around the North End on Commercial just to avoid it here.
Need bike lanes or cycle tracks on Nashua St, especially northbound.
Need bike lanes or cycle tracks on Merrimac St.
This is a key connection for bikes to the Longfellow that is made quite difficult by the lack of facilities.
Need bike lanes or cycle tracks on Congress St
Need bike lanes or cycle tracks on Congress St between State St and Water St. Lots of traffic. Very stressful.

I've seen many close calls when drivers turning right from Summer Street onto Melcher street nearly run down pedestrians in the crosswalk. The road allows for fast right hand turns and should be slowed down.
Need more crosswalks on Milk St. Not all intersections have them.

The angled parking here is a disaster waiting to happen. Drivers backing out cannot see cars & bikes when they back out.  Consider changing this to reverse-in angled parking (or get rid of the parking)
Too many drivers are using the bike lane to get around traffic. This is very dangerous.
Too many drivers are using the bus lane.
No safe way to ride the Jway over Rte 9. Path below doesn't connect. Please install a protected bike lane on the Jway over Rte 9!
Lots of illegal parking in the right lane during rush hour.
Need a bike lane or cycle track on this block.
Need 2-way cycle track here since bicycling through Boston Common and Public Garden is illegal.
It's literally insane. :(
Need two-way bike facility on Charles St. Going northbound currently requires long detour to Esplanade and back.
Too many drivers turning right onto Storrow from the left lane. Very dangerous and rude. Need better pavement markings and signage.
Rampant double parking in front of CVS (including the CVS delivery truck EVERY THURSDAY EVENING at rush hour!)
Need two-way bike facility on Arlington St, especially since bicycling is prohibited in Public Garden.
Need bike lanes or cycle tracks on Columbus Ave from Dartmouth St to Charles St.
Need bike lanes or cycle tracks on Stuart St

Need bike lane or cycle track on Washington St from Kneeland St to pedestrian zone
Need bike lane on Washington St from Kneeland St to pedestrian zone

Linden Street is a direct artery to the highway. Motorists do not recognize this as a residential area.
Sidewalks need to be installed along the frontage of the liquor store and carwash. Both businesses need to remove all frontage pavement except for necessary and reasonable driveways.

Morton St. needs barrier-protected commuter bike/pedestrian paths to connect residents in the outlying Boston neighborhoods of Hyde Park, Roslindale, S. Jamaica Plain, Mattapan and W. Dorchester to rapid transit.

The old road lines on I90 E are still visible from the most recent roadwork. problem @ 7:45AM. sun rises the old lines are far more reflective than the true lines. Many cars follow the old lines instead of the true lines
no crosswalk or light, no safe  entry to pjp park.

The traffic lights do not sync efficiently so cars stuck at a light ahead take up space between the traffic lights and gridlock occurs when lights behind the first one turn green. Need more than 30 sec.
Drivers rarely stop at the stop signs at intersections of High & School and High & Pearl. And if they do stop (or almost stop) it is typically in the crosswalks, not before the crosswalks.

The traffic lights are creating unnecessary traffic. They do not sync efficiently so cars stuck at a light ahead take up space between the traffic lights and gridlock occurs when lights behind the first one turn green.
There is a crosswalk here that drivers routinely ignore despite pedestrians trying to cross. It happens consistently all of the time EVERY DAY, EVERY HOUR.

This light seems unnecessary.  there is not enough traffic flow here that cars and pedestrians need a red light to cross, or to turn left from Hanover onto Commercial.  A flashing yellow would suffice all around to keep cars from speeding.
not enough time to cross both W and E Comm Ave and no dedicated walk-only time to cross from MBTA to SE corner of Comm Ave and St Paul St.
Cars, bikes, pedestrians, MBTA - all crossing around the same intersection. Who thought this would not create HUGe problems? It's time for the B line to become an elevated rail.
Drivers crossing into the carriageway have very low visibility of the people crossing from the tracks. One more reason for the T to become an elevated rail and jsut connect train to sidewalks.
Merging from Alford St (bridge) into the rotary here is terrifying and dangerous on a bike, yet people use this rotary for commuting throughout the day, ever day. Please make it safer.
Needs four way stop signs
Cars often roll into the intersection, ignoring the stop sign and not looking out for pedestrians.
Students and state house workers cross well away from the cross walk and with little to no regard for traffic
This intersection needs a small roundabout, curb extensions, painted/raised crosswalks, pedestrian signage, landscaping and street furniture to make cut-through drivers slow down for  residents.

Needs curb extensions, landscaped island w/ benches, raised crosswalks, rumble lines, narrower curb radiuses, better signalization, prominent wayfinding signage, barrier-protected bike lanes, green stormwater drainage, sheltered bus stops

The 5-way intersection is dangerous for pedestrians and bicyclists to cross, impossible when it snows. 3 densely-populated pocket neighborhoods are cut off from each other and from active routes to two shopping centers and other local stores
Drivers coming from center street into the rotary do not yield to drivers in the rotary.
no light, freeway empties onto gallivan cross at your peril.

The loss of a second vehicle lane here has caused major back up of traffic.  Because vehicles cannot turn right in a separate lane, cars are backed up for three cycles of the light change, which is very long at this intersection

Ped'trians cross Summer St at will-along its entire length. Also, the lighting is relatively poor from Atlantic Av to Dorchester Av. The installation of fencing and planters, similar to Congress St, would channel pedestrians into the crosswalks.

Gardena is the busier of the two streets and is basically a through street.  However there are no stop signs on Etna (going either northbound or southbound) and there is a strong likelihood of a collision as neither Gardena nor Etna have stop signs.

Very dangerous crossing with commuters running red lights, with pedestrians in the crosswalks, during commutes.  No walk/stop signals for pedestrians.  DCR added crosswalk LED overhead lighting which has been a vast improvement for walker safety.
Red lights appear to be optional, especially people driving up Washington street towards commonwealth ave
Many students cross the street here to get onto Northeastern Campus from Residential buildings. The addition of a cross walk would be nice to help make people aware of crossing pedestrians

The divider between the highway and surface road juts out into the left lane of the surface road. The cars in the left lane of Cross St. swerve into the right lane overtime to not jump the curb nearly causing an accident.
Separating the bike lane here is extremely dangerous because cars won't always yield when turning and when you are in a separated lane there are no opportunities to swerve.
Crossing Commonwealth Ave at the Chestnut hill ave t stop on the B Line is dangerous, insane and scary.  The light does not give you enough time to cross four lanes of traffic and the train tracks.
\Crossing between the island and the BHCC sidewalk
column7: \"\"walk\"\" is lit for only a fraction of the time that the traffic has a red light. So people cross when they don't have the \"\"walk\"\". Can the walk signal be adjusted to be lit for the full amount of...\""

COMMENTS: The Commonwealth Hotel ALWAYS have people and staff in the cycling lane. I got nearly doored here once by a valet parked halfway in the cycling lane. The staff couldn't care less  and shouted at me for alleged speeding (no such thing on a bike....)

The traffic lights set up here are incorrect! On green it shows a green arrow for left turning vehicles. This gives the wrong impression that the way is always clear and no crossing traffic is to be expected.

People park in the no-parking area right at Tremont and Tip Top, significantly reducing visibility. People speed coming around the corner and it's an accident waiting to happen. I've contacted police countless times, but minimal enforcement.

Please put the guardrail on the other side of the bike lane. the bike lanes are narrow and have frequent drains; cars speed by and do not respect the bike lane, and the lanes are frequently not plowed. Plus the added danger of crosswinds.

Every time I have to turn onto Faneuil St I  have to practically go as far as the middle of the crossing to see if cars are coming from my left. Cars are parked all the way to the corner of Hobson and Faneuil making it impossible to see cars coming.
Left turn signel time is too short to turn. And also other side traffic has longer timer for green light, so realy hard to make left turn here.
The Tufts shuttle buses stop in the travel lanes to let passengers off. They stop and start abruptly and don't signal.
...time that it's safe to cross (i.e., the full time the traffic has red)? And BTW, why the 250 character limit?
The bike lane is to the right of the right turning lane - need traffic study. Makes it dangerous for bikes and difficult for cars
Getting to the southwest bike corridor from this intersection can be very dangerous on bicycle  cars race to get through strip, congested with bus traffic, cars dropping passengers off etc.

I am hit and run victim here. I had no helmet and had brain injury. I own helmet but helmet straps became tangled so I just stopped using it. If helmets were required by law I would have had one on! REQUIRE bike helmets?

This happens on BOTH sides of the road. In front of the shopping center and the YMCA all times of the day. Blocking the bike lane makes it extremely dangerous for cyclist that must merge back and forth.
The metal joints here are extremely dangerous for bikers--a cyclist got his front tire stuck in one last week, the bike instantly stopped under him, and he flipped over the front.
no bike lanes and motorists do not respect cyclists in the road, driving by very close
Please separate bike and walking paths on the Esplanade
Road is very broken up around the T tracks, bikes have to avoid big holes, leading them into traffic.

Drivers using this road to go from commonwealth to chestnut hill drive very quickly down this road, but there are a lot of pedestrians crossing the street and the driving visibility is hindered by all the cars parked on the sides.

Agreed with nearby safety issues documented here - the roadway has deteriorated because of speeding cars.  The surface needs to be repaved and new paint or bike infrastructure would make it safe for cyclists and pedestrians accessing the Arboretum.
This intersection needs a light; coming from Scottfield onto Kelton it is very difficult to see traffic coming from either direction.
Delivery trucks are double parked here every morning.
There are several potholes and seams that require cyclists to take the lane. This is especially treacherous because vehicles in the middle lane don't always signal when they're turning right.

Almost every morning I watch dozens of people get off the buses at the bus stop and walk across the road (not at the intersection) effectively shutting down traffic. It's not safe and it's a pain in the ass if you're a driver.
although it is posted as no turn on red, almost all cars turn on red both from Commonwealth Ave, and also form the service road onto Wallingford Road
people coming down Walworth routinely drive too fast for this narrow road.  there are students who wait for a bus here and have to cross and the cars routinely drive too fast.
Cars on Brookline Ave. routinely run red lights.

People cut through on Tip Top to avoid the Oak Square lights. They often speed through, despite there being children at play and small animals about. Pizza delivery guys think they're on the autobahn.
Incredibly dangerous intersection for bicycles. Very difficult merge to the left across two lanes of automobiles on the right coming from Mugar Way.
Automobiles move much too fast for this street. Needs traffic calming. Very threatening to bicyclists.
Very difficult for bicyclists to make a left turn onto Sudbury. Must navigate between fast moving cars. Please add protected intersection with bike lanes and signals.
Bicyclists are at great risk here. Autos attempting to turn right and bicyclists needing to continue straight. Please add cycle track with bike signal for safety.
A LOT!!! Drivers here are completely nutjobs speeding like they have a baby to deliver!
This crossing is literally the design of an asterisk! If people think Boston rotaries are bad, wait till you meet the Boston asterisk!
People double park Infront of BU dorms
Better lighting needed for pedestrians crossing from the State House to City Oasis.  Cars turning left from Beacon can't see us at all and it's a very unsafe crossing.

Need signs, paint, enforcement that cars cannot park within 20 ft. of all intersections.
#0 miles per hour in residential zone, cars go fastter, very bad for pedestrians in NEIGHBORHOOD.

There needs to be (landscaped) bumpouts that will narrow the lanes and require cars to turn 90 degrees.

All of American Legion Hwy/Parkway is wide and wooded, and has plenty of space for multimodal commuter and recreational transportation including separate lanes for cars, buses, bicycles and pedestrians.
The valets for the restaurant on the corner double park here as well as congregate in the street, blocking bike and Silver Line traffic.

Few people use turn signal to indicate which direction they're heading. Are they going down Arlington or continuing on Faneuil? One never knows. Meanwhile, you're waiting to turn onto Faneuil with the double whammy of no signals and people speeding.
This area gets very clogged at rush hour. Making things worse is the continuous issue of double parking at the Oak Square restaurants on Washington.

Please put bike lane on other side of parked cars. Lower risk of a cyclist hitting an open door or of a car hitting a cyclist when parking. Plus cars cannot pull over into the bike lane and will not kill cyclists if they swerve

People constantly double park on Huntington and make the road unsafe for drivers and bikes. Especially unsafe because drivers trying to get around cars are blind to bikes that are also trying to get around them.
People RARELY yield, even when a ped is already in the crosswalk
When turning off Murdock on to Cambridge Street, vehicles parked on Cambridge street  east of Murdock, make it difficult to see oncoming traffic from the East.
There should be  a stop sign for cars coming down Egleston towards Boylston.  People roll into the intersection and I've nearly been hit many times as a pedestrian and cyclist.

Because there's no time when pedestrians can cross independently of traffic moving and there are so many lanes to cross, cars are constantly turning into crosswalks, often without using their turn signals.

cars are always double parked at the dunking donuts and the SL4/5 busses are always delayed.
parents picking up their children at the Boston Ballet School ALWAYS double park and slow traffic.
Drivers treat this road like a racetrack; this needs a stop light for pedestrians to get across Lincoln St.
Drivers often go much too fast down this stretch.

Cars turn right across my path all the time. There are no dedicated bike lanes, I fear for my life in this intersection which is long as has multiple streets crossing it and multiple directions of travel for cars.

Often I enter the intersection when the light is green, not turning yellow or anything, but green and shortly after it turns yellow. The intersection is so long that by the time I get to railroad tracks it's already red.
Walk signal on intersection to the south is responsive, but signal to the north wait for walk signal is in minutes

Southbound drivers turning onto Harvard do not yield to the Northbound traffic once their protected left goes away. They regularly almost crash into northbound drivers going to straight once the northbound light changes to green.
How specific would you like? It's insanity. This road has too many lanes and drivers treat it like a personal highway.
There's a BU Shuttle stop here leading me to believe there's BU facilities or housing here. Constant double parking in bike lane. All vehicles with driver only. Just waiting....
Drivers typically don't stop for stop signs.

Turning left onto the far south side of boylston is uncomfortable. The bike lane on arlington is technically the left lane, but that set you up to have to cross traffic to make the left onto the far side of boylston. Confusing how it should work.
It takes a year to cross here. People don't wait for the light because of it.
I drive and bike here. Ppl speed. Visibility is poor. This road is treated as a raceway.
Poor markings. Poor visibility. No bike infra. Poor ped infra. Speeding. Too many games of chicken. I've had numerous close calls on bike and driving here.

This stop sign is never fully stopped at. Lots of rolling stops which promotes higher speeds along Day Street. Additionally, drivers don't yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk because they are so sloppy at stopping.

This is a busy intersection and while drivers do yield, pedestrians do not do their due courtesy of at least ensuring the driver sees them to cross. Put crossing signs up to ensure safety of pedestrians and drivers alike.
Cars are always double parked with no one in them between Fidelis Way and Washington Street in the Carriage Lane heading west.
The three way intersection stop signs are ignored almost as a matter of routine.
Cannot go by this block without seeing someone double parked. Makes the sharp turn onto Foster that much harder.

'Walk' light across Westland comes too soon after start of the left-turn red light for traffic going NW on Mass. Ave. & veering left onto Westland. People start walking across Westland before traffic to Westland has cleared intersection.
Very rough where metal joiners meet roadway, forcing a biker out into the full lane of traffic.
Cars parked on the corner limit sightlines.
CONSTANTLY.
Domino's driver said he HAD TO DOUBLE PARK IN THE BIKE LANE BECAUSE BU ORDERED PIZZA. Too bad. I guess human life is less important than pizza.
There is no legal/safe crossing for Naples road but ppl just STAND IN THE BIKE LANE while waiting to make a run for it across Comm.
People double park, pull into bike lane to drop ppl off w/o looking. I've had numerous close calls here.

There's a problem with band vehicles in front of the Paradise - they're ALWAYS too wide for the parking space and extend into bike lane. Unsafe & invites DOUBLE PARKING. Paradise needs a better solution. They don't NEED to park out front.

There are often accidents at this intersections because people will take u turns from the carriage road or they try to cross 4 lanes & the t on a left. There needs to be more signage to make the intersection safer.
There seems to be a valet for this building and 4 days out of 5 there's vehicles with drivers idling in the bike lane and/or multiple vehicles parked in the bike lane.

Motorists honk & yell ride in bike lane. Bike lane is on left. BY LAW I HAVE RIGHT 2 B IN ROAD. Was harassed by a person in van for 4 blocks. Repeated honking at me & told me to get in bike lane. Told me I might get hurt or killed.
this is not news

There are three roadways that converge just outside of Haymarket Station (one of which is bus way). The light is almost always red for pedestrians trying to cross Sudbury. Lots of crossing against the light occurs because the wait is too long.

The brick sidewalk on Surface Rd between State and Central is caving in. When it rains, there is a HUGE LAKE aceoss the sidewalk. Pedestrians often step into the street to pass ....Surface Rd traffic is fast moving. This is really dangerous.
Any form of travel through this intersection is treacherous. There need to be left-turn lights going all four directions.
Poorly designed intersection.  Cars can't see to turn, so they accelerate without seeing pedestrians.  The turning occurs in advance of the where the road is, so they drive toward oncoming cars.

Northbound traffic on Chestnut Hill Ave has a left turn arrow, but southbound traffic has a delayed green instead.  There is no signage to indicate that the southbound traffic has a delayed green, leading to people turning left into oncoming traffic.
Walk sign is barely sufficient to reach median. There are no curb cuts on the median, making it difficult to reach buttons to request a walk sign in order to cross the remaining lanes of traffic.
It is not clear whether a left turn from Chestnut Hill ave southbound onto Commonwealth Ave westbound is only permitted on green arrow, or if one can turn on green without the green arrow.
Because there are usually large vehicles parked near the crosswalks, it's hard to see if the road is clear and it's ok to cross Beacon.
I walk, bike, and drive here.Drivers frequently speed from Fuller to Gallivan.Hard to cross. Could City install a sign that tells people how fast they are driving?

Washington in Codman Sq area is tricky for biking.Please give it a look! Lots of gridlock, road rage, jaywalking, cars pulling out of businesses, etc.  What can be done to make for smoother, lower stress bicycling here?

The pedestrian walk signal is timed with the green light. Buses, trucks, and cars make right turns from Albany onto Melnea Cass at high speeds. By the time all the vehicles have turned right, there is often little or no time left on the walk signal.
The fact that Sumner is one way needs to be more clearly marked. I've seen multiple tractor trailers turning up Sumner from Jeffries street - not noticing it's one way.

THere is not a dedicated right turn only lane - it was taken away when the wide bike lanes were installed.  Traffic is backed up far too long and bikes can't get to the left to avoid cars turning right onto Atlantic Ave.
People going in and out of pizza place mostly. Bike lane almost always blocked.

There is insufficient road markings on the northbound side of Everett street. We need to designate a left or right turn only lane such that when two lanes form, both lanes don't have to merge together in the middle of the intersection.
Often see people make an illegal and unexpected left turn from Comm ave (going east) onto Brighton Ave, through a narrow slit from where the A line tracks used to be.

MODE: protected bike lane from Packards corner
COMMENTS: \This is statistically one of the most dangerous stretches of cycling in Boston. \"\"Dooring\"\" is a huge problem here. Please make a separated"

In this one block the bike lane moves from the far right, to the far left (three lanes over), yet there is no place to safely transition through three lanes of traffic. Please make a green bike path that crosses the three lanes.
Often the valet signs (foldable white signs) from the hotel or the oyster bar are placed in the cycling lane.

The road has sharrows painted on them (SE dir), and there are 'bike route' signs. Still, cars overtake like maniacs here, squeezing cyclists of the road only to get stuck again at the wash. sq. traffic lights.
Because the crosswalks are set to make people walk more than they have to in order to make it more convenient for cars. One of the worst intersection around.

There is a lot of double parking here and parking in the fire lane. There are a lot of trucks load/ unloading all the time. Sometimes it is so busy with cars and trucks that ambulances can not pass. Potentially life-threatening situation
Relentless parking in the cycling lane during the evening. I come from Longwood and make a left turn onto Brookline and most of the time have to re-merge with traffic to get around parked cars.

The number of BU students who just walk across the road in flocks, despite the traffic having a green light, is atrocious. Vehicles constantly have to hit the breaks and stop and wait despite the light being green.

The lower part of Burrell is a two way. And at times there are stand-offs between cars going both directions. Because no one wants to back up all the way to the end of the street or at the first corner. Because cars are parked on both sides.
Service road needs a designated bike lane.

Cycling west up Comm ave from here is far too dangerous on the main road (fast cars, blind corner), and near impossible up the service road (heavy incline). Please build a designated bike lane going west, on the south side of the street.

Cars frequently parked/waiting in the skimpy bike lane here. That on top of being doored by parked vehicles makes this stretch very dangerous for cyclists. Needs a seperated, protected bike lane, to prevent dooring, and illegal bike lane parking.
Thanks for changing the signal timings to increase the walk time for the SW Corridor. However, there do not need to be 4 vehicle travel lanes. Queue storage is not actually an issue.
Cars ignore stop sign frequently.

Riding the bike path at night puts cyclists right up against cars with their headlights on and makes it very difficult to see at night. I'm sure my 1000 lumen bike light is blinding drivers too. Add vertical fencing to block light.

The road was repaved last year and carries a lot of bike traffic, but no bike lane was installed. Cars get really aggravated because there is not enough room to pass and it makes riding very uncomfortable.

It takes a long time to cross here on foot. People usually walk straight across sudbury to go south on congress without the walk sign and cause a queue for cars turning right from congress onto sudbury.
The sidewalks need to be wider to accommodate all the pedestrian traffic headed to the T station. There are a number of obstructions like light poles and control cabinets that block the sidewalk.

column7: including frequent tour buses ignore \"\"no turn on red\"\".\""

COMMENTS: People coming from the Yawkey station want to go straight across beacon which makes perfect sense. There is no crosswalk there & they need to travel across 4 travel lanes to get to the north side of beacon. A median and crosswalk would be awesome

This intersection needs a lead in for bikes. I usually go just before the light turns green to turn R onto arlington so that I don't have to jockey with cars to get in the lane. A few seconds head start for bikes will make them more visible.

People who live & park their cars on Kinross st drive the wrong way on this one-way street in order to exit onto Commonwealth Ave. It's also a blind corner because of a concrete wall on the sw side. Seen/heard many near accidents.
Criss cross of people from main road turning right onto Wallingford, and people from service road merging left onto main road, makes many near accidents.
Main road needs designated bike lane. Cars speed through the service roads for many blocks, and don't expect bikes around ups and down and turns of Comm ave.

Extremely dangerous intersection, where two lanes and two service roads of traffic cross into each other on the same light, through a set of train tracks. (when going west). Service road on NE side is one way, but service road on NW is two way.
Extend this one protected bike lane all the way down Mass ave. It's useless being just one block long.

MODE: protected bike lane from Packards corner

There is poor poor lighting on all four corners of Park St and Beacon St. It feels unsafe to cross the street at night, even when using the cross walk sign.

Private buses as well as general traffic park in the bus stop and the bike lane.  This forces the SL4/5 to stop in the bike lane, and also forces people to make the right onto Kneeland from the center lane.

Valet's in particular leave multiple vehicles unattended for long stretches.  They also park them to the left of the lane, leaving not even enough room for a bike to pass abreast without changing into the general traffic lane.
At the least, sharrows would encourage bicycles' rights.

Drivers heading east on Bynner and making a left turn onto S Huntington don't yield to traffic traveling west. This is made especially dangerous since it's difficult to see the eastbound vehicles due to the steep grade of Bynner St.

The pavement around the curbs of the raised crosswalk is crumbling, posing a danger for cyclists.
The pavement around the curbs of the brick inlay crosswalk is crumbling, posing a danger to cyclists.
Drivers drive the wrong way on the one-way street here.
Drivers drive the wrong way on the one-way
There's a big ugly elevated highway down the center of the emerald necklace.  At least let's use it as like a free roof for a tennis court or something!
Drivers drive the wrong way on the one-way street
The road is too narrow to have parking on both sides and have two-way traffic.
no sidewalk on one side of street. have to walk in street which is very dangerous

This intersection has always been scary on a bike, but even more so since the Longfellow Bridge has been under construction. It is difficult for a cyclist to get on the bridge safely from Cambridge st given the lack of clear biking and driving lanes.
All summer the kids in the projects have their run of this park until ten or eleven pm.  d14 should roll up the parks at 8 like it says on the sign.
drivers run lights all the time here. The lights are well timed but especially with the stress of making the bridge, it;s very dangerous at this intersection
Unfortunately bikes are a nuisance in the eyes of car drivers on Commonwealth Ave thru Brighton Ave thru Washington St thru Tremont st in Newton Corner
no fence to prevent people from crossing four lanes to get to Arboretum and no signs to indicate nearby crosswalk.

just about everyone double parks on Charles st, so it's effectively 1 most of the time. Dangerous for bikers who have to swiftly change lanes into aggressive vehicular traffic. This is why so many lights are run - so we can get ahead of traffic.

Death comes from crossing the criminally poorly laid out bike lane/highway entrance cross.  The entrance is marked right.  Bike lane should be protected up until the cross over, and need signs for cars cutting through bike lane.

There's a contractor that runs a business out of his house and is constantly backing trucks up, stopping traffic, or having his guys park in the middle of the street all day every day.  What the heck?

Stupid yoga class flunkies drive up here, turn the wrong way up the one way street.  Go back to notice you suburbanite.

drivers dont stop for pedestrians. trucks and city buses speed through this intersection
road needs paving. sidewalks also non-existent
As Park Vale Avenue is a feeder street into a number of one-way streets in the area, people speed down Park Vale.  At times it is quite dangerous for the people who live and walk on the street.

I work on Mass Ave. This light between Haviland St & Belvedere St/Mass Ave is run thru every day. Drivers do not obey the lights & run the red light daily. Ive almost been hit several times when the safe to cross light is on

As the only marked crosswalk are at Harvard Ave and Allston Street, there are a number of people who routinely cross Brighton Ave in order to access CVS/Dunkin Donuts parking lot and cross 4 lanes of traffic to do so.
There are no cross walks. This is a dangerous area to cross the River Way.
Cars turning onto Cambridge st are just trying to get in the lane while the light is green, not looking for bikers in the lane who might be heading over the bridge.
In front of the convenience store, people always park in the street like jerk offs

as an elderly pedestrian, trying to cross the T tracks at this large intersection is very difficult.  Why isn't there a consistent flat walking surface along the tracks as there are at many other T/crosswalk places?

This bridge is constantly up during rush hour making everyone late for everything. Is there no way to schedule the boats so that the bridge does not need to go up at rush hour times? I've often seen the bridge go up as many as 4 times in 1 hr!
Would be great if Cushman Road, Gardena, Moncalm, Elmira, and others were turned into one-way roads. With parking on both sides it causes difficultly when two vehicles meet going opposite directions.

Cars do not yield for pedestrians in the crosswalk at the intersection of Brahms St. and Washington St.  Additionally cars park right up to the crosswalk making visibility difficult. A signal is needed at this crosswalk.
Bike lane ends before the intersection with Riverway.  Makes the street dangerous.  Please continue it all the way into Brookline.
Cars parking within the intersection making turning for a vehicle challenging, and impossible for emergency vehicles. Resident parking should be brought to this area of Brighton.

Should be two way for bikes on this block (or one way for all users, but in the opposite direction), in order to provide access to the bridge over Storrow Drive without riding on Beacon St. Beacon St is too busy to ride on safely or comfortably.

The blocks between Copley Sq. (or really the bridge over Storrow Dr. to the Esplanade) and the SW Corridor Park are key for bike connectivity & there should be *separated* bike infrastructure on this segment to connect the bike grid. Plenty of room.
