The bike/ped bridge over Storrow Drive is essential, but (1) it is too narrow, (2) the railings are scary low, (3) the right angles at each end are awkward (esp. given 1 and 2).
I am almost hit by a car every time I'm in this crosswalk. Drivers turning from Comm are speeding across the T tracks & service road, and aren't looking for pedestrians.

Pedestrians kept waiting when there is no oncoming traffic when crossing 1st leg of Beacon (toward Reservoir T). Cars turning L from ChestnutHill can't hit them so no reason why can't cross to 1st median. Walk signal too short in this case.

For people biking through the SW Corridor Park, there are stairs to Mass Ave here, with an ADA ramp. However, the ramp is narrow with a sharp switchback, very awkward to use on a bike. Plenty of space for a longer straight ramp.
There are a number of BPS bus stops along this stretch and it is impossible to cross the street because people speed and there is extremely low visibility coming up Walter from the Arboretum.
There is a restaurant on this corner and cars on constantly double or triple parked in this high volume intersection when they go in to get takeout.
Cars fly down this street
People speed up E Brookline St.
Drivers run well past the stop line before stopping, and block this crosswalk.
Drivers turning onto Malden St rarely yield to oncoming pedestrian traffic here.
Cars frequently block the crosswalk at W. Newton and Columbus Ave at the red light.
Many drivers ignore the crosswalk signals and nearly hit pedestrians in the crosswalk on a daily basis.
There isn't a pedestrian walk signal/red light for cars. It feels like I'm playing a game of chance. This entire stretch of road is poorly lit. It doesn't feel conducive to pedestrian safety.

The street is very narrow considering it's a two way street. People drive very fast and given that cars park on the street, I don't know if they can see pedestrians who might be trying to cross the street.
When turning left onto Spring Park Ave from Burr Street, because of the curve in the road and the cars parked on the corner, it's nearly impossible to see cars approaching from either direction.
People do not allow bikes to have right of way, often speed around bikes going into oncoming traffic lane to do so.
Drivers don't stop for pedestrians in the cross walk
Drivers don't stop for pedestrians in the cross walk
Double parking, mostly to run into Mike's Pastry
Cars don't stop for pedestrians in the cross walk

Pedestrians get a walk light at the same time as cars getting a green light and the cars are turning into the crosswalk.  The cars frequently don't yield to pedestrians and are often going too fast. It's terrifying to cross here.
lights take too long to change, really backs up traffic, should be a yield
People turn right on red coming up Tremont onto Stuart (they don't see the sign) while pedestrians are crossing. Then everyone gets angry. I worry someone will get hit and/or will lead to road rage.
Drivers turning left from Harrison to Reynolds Way frequently fail to yield to oncoming and concurrent pedestrian traffic.
Drivers turning onto Harrison northbound should have a no turn on red here and pedestrians should have a concurrent walk signal with the Harrison Ave light.

I walk, drive and bike through this intersection regularly. It is not signed and it is not clear who has the right of way (other than pedestrians in the crosswalk). It should probably be an all way stop.
The crosswalk across Pelham St is not signalized, but the one across W. Dedham is, confusing drivers crossing the intersection. The crosswalks should be combined and moved closer to Washington St.
Drivers block this intersection after the lights change.
Cars on northern lanes are trying to merge to CONTINUE onto N. Beacon toward Parsons Street while southern lanes are merging TOWARD those cars trying to onto Soldiers Field.

There are three lanes of cars coming from Charles St. Cars in all three lanes attempt to get into the tunnel ahead. It needs to be made clear which lanes on Charles St are meant for which lane up ahead- Martha Rd, the tunnel, or the left lane.
Cars turning onto Waltham St frequently disregard pedestrian traffic. Crosswalks should be raised.

People park their cars in the middle of the street here on Sundays and it makes it very difficult for pedestrians and cyclists using the roadway. It makes crossing here very difficult.There should be a stop sign at every intersection on Columbus Ave.

Drivers turning into the parking area here routinely drive on the sidewalk and sometimes block the sidewalk when parking here. There should be a barrier installed between the sidewalk and the parking lot.

\This key stretch of the SW Corridor \"\"Path\"\" is just a narrow sidewalk. Many conflicts between pedestrians (incl children going to the park) and cyclists. Difficult to switch to biking on street here (even if going in right dir) due to massive curb.\""

The crosswalks and pedestrian signals here are extremely confusing (and slow), esp. the diagonal crosswalk. Esp. dangerous for the many new people visiting the hospital who are encountering the intersection & nonstandard crosswalk for the first time.

Cars regularly speed through this area, especially during rush hours. It makes it very dangerous to cross here as many cars will not stop for pedestrians and may not see you when they're speeding. There should be a flashing cross walk or speed sign.

It is almost impossible for drivers turning onto Harrison from E. Springfield St to see traffic coming from the left. The closest parking space shoudl probably be removed and a bump-out installed to prevent illegal blocking.
Cars turning onto Boylston don't yield. Pedestrian traffic here is way to heavy to allow right on red. There should be a no turn on red sign here.
Drivers ignore this crosswalk.

There should be way more bike parking in front of the library. Right now there are like 4 two-bike City of Boston racks (in poor condition), and the library website officially suggests just locking bikes to a handrail next to the library.
People drive very fast down this road, and given that it's a steep hill, I can never tell if they can see me walking. I always have to be very careful.
The biggest pothole in Boston.
people walk against the light, assuming that they have the right to walk regardless of the lights.

The walk signal across New Chardon is not coordinated with the stop lights at either end. Pedestrians should have the right of way whenever the corresponding lights are red. This is a major path of travel for commuters.
The left turn from Congress Southbound onto North St. creates an unsafe environment. Peds ignore left turn arrow and there is on-coming traffic.
The cars from North St. Constantly block this intersection. North St. should be one way inbound from the highway to accomodate traffic flow.
While on Revere St, tough to see on-coming traffic from W. Cedar.
There are numerous people not using crosswork. Difficult to see coming around corner.
Cars always doubleparked on Haverill for Garden events. No-stopping zone.
Difficult left turn onto Harvard Ave - Left turns should not be allowed at Intersection.

This is a very stressful place to ride. Lots of cars.  No place for bicyclists unless you just sit in the gridlock.  There should be a place for us so we can move - like a cycletrack. I often ride on the sidewalk here.
Insufficient space between moving traffic and parked cars for bikes to be traveling next to the cars, so often necessary to ride on sidewalk.Then,at the light,vehicles are usually blocking the box.
not enough signage. It is a confusing intersection with traffic coming off Everett Bridge (who rarely pay attention to posted yield sign) crossing traffic going straight on Everett towards Lincoln.
the nearest crosswalk is 100 feet from front door of library so people cross in the middle of the street.

Lincoln Street runs 3/4 mile without stoplights of stop signs so it is a popular cut thru. There are few posted speed limit signs and they are widely ignored. Very dangerous for pedestrians and bicycles.
It is very difficult to see left onto Causeway to see on-coming traffic with a very poorly placed City Advertisement sign and left turns should not be allowed.
Cars constantly are in the wrong lane turning from Congress.

Stressful place to bike because cars in the left lane may be turning and cars in the right may be turning. I usually have to ride on the sidewalk to get ahead of the cars and then sit in the crosswalk waiting to cross Columbia Rd.

There needs to be Left and Right Turn Only signs in the tunnel before the Purchase Street off-ramp. People jump lanes all the time at the last minute to get right or left and it is unsafe and clogs the exit to the tunnel. Thank you.
This is a very popular/busy cut-through side street and also extremely narrow. Would be better off as a one way.
Traffic flow should allow southbound travel on Canal during Garden events to remove pressure on Causeway St. Dangerous to have cars & peds.
Berkely St. On-Ramp to storrow would function 100% better if it were 1 foot wider. Not wide enough for two cars to travel at same time, forces mini-merge and backs traffic up to Boylston St.
Cars from Carriage road merge onto Comm Ave mainline westbound without yielding.
There is a very long wait time to get a walk signal.

The walk from Andrew Station to 1010 Mass ave (where I work) is not safe. Cars on 93 do not stop. There is trash everywhere, this neighborhood deserves better. Maybe a walking tunnel or bridge for people?

many drivers glide thru the stop sign at 10-15 mph never coming to anything resembling a full stop even though they are turning onto a busy street with traffic coming from 3 directions and lots of bicycles.
drivers, who frequently take advantage of the long straightaway do not slow for pedestrians crossing
Very poor visibility from stop sign on Back St & Berkley.
Hard to bike here because not enough room between traveling cars and the sidewalk for bikes. Would be great to have a cycletrack!
I constantly see drivers run red lights here.
The walk signal is not long enough to get across.
This is a small residential street.  Yet, cars tend to speed here as if it is a highway.
Very difficult to see traffic coming from the left (from downtown).  There is a blind curve preventing pedestrians from seeing oncoming traffic.  There is a crosswalk here but no traffic light.
People do not use the crosswalk lanes to cross the square in any direction across Maverick Street. People often cross mid-block  - with such a wide roadway, it becomes quite dangerous.
Very frequently, vehicles park on Sumner (firestation side) just at Orleans. Due to poor line of sight, it is next to impossible to see oncoming traffic.
Cars making a right from Atlantic don't yield to pedestrians. Could be a signal issue - they have a green at the same time pedestrians have the walk signal.
Codman Island has been crushed by cars twice in recent weeks.

MODE: making it very dangerous for cars in the other two lanes who often have to unexpectedly merge from three lanes into two.\",Unassigned,-71.10509983107363
location: \Heading inbound on Beacon St. at the Park St. intersection
COMMENTS: cars often get in the \"\"left turn only\"\" lane and go straight"
The wheelchair ramps for a cross walk were put in but the cross walk has never been painted and TONS of people cross here.
The stop sign fell down and it is lying on the sidewalk
The crosswalk doesn't line up with the exits from the T station, as a result pedestrians cross away from the crosswalk.
The sidewalks on this stretch of 1st Street are either nonexistent or too narrow and in poor condition. Whatever replaces the power plant needs a bigger setback.
I see people run this stop sign (not even slowing down) on a regular basis, particularly in the morning.

Drivers can be aggressive. Bikes want to go straight, and cars want to go left or right to get onto the highway. It is difficult for bikes to get into the center lane to go straight.  People on bikes need protection and/or a dedicated light cycle.
This sweeping right turn allows car drivers to make the turn at high speed, which is very dangerous for people who bike.  We need traffic calming measures here asap!
The bike lane disappears into a driving lane. Very difficult to get from the bike lane to a lane that continues straight through the intersection

Cars turning R onto Huntington off the J-way exit block or go into the R turn-only lane. Often they don't want to turn on S. Huntington & refuse to turn on green arrow. Causes honking & clogged lanes - very stressful/dangerous on bike
\Lane is painted as \"\"sharrow\"\" but nobody knows what that means"

This is one of the most dangerous bike intersections in Boston and needs improvement ASAP. Large Potholes. We need a dedicated bike lane. Riders could easily get doored by parked cars, hit a pothole, rail track, lose control and be hit by a bus/train

This merge is awful. Cars pile up and it sometimes turns into three lanes merging into one, approaching the intersection. Ask the bus drivers. They will have cars trying to squeeze in on either side of them.
The crosswalk between Maverick Stn and the Tedeschi's is often obscured by buses. Drivers seldom slow for the crosswalk, so crossing must be done very carefully if buses are present.

This section of Neptune could use two-lane markings at the light for straight and left and straight and right lanes. When cars split like this, there is less back-up in the horrible Saratoga/Neptune/Chelsea triangle.

Westbound traffic that basically uses Bremen as a cut-through to skip the lights on Bennington Street contribute a great amount to the chaos that is this intersection, along with Saratoga/Neptune/Chelsea intersection.
People continuously run this stop sign.

It's almost out-of-season now, but there is a drainage issue at the high school which sends water down across the sidewalk and fans out. In the winter, this turns into a thick, glass-like sheet of ice that's  impossible to walk on, as it's on a hill.

Pedestrians cross the eastbound Commonwealth Ave lanes while cars are making U turns from westbound to eastbound Commonwealth Ave.  The light is short so cars rush through the left turn/u-turn and can't see pedestrians before they're too close
Long intersection with no crosswalks.  visibility is poor and there is no good place to cross
Pedestrians on the south side of Washington St cross Chestnut Hill with the green light instead of waiting for the 4-way cross signal.

The bushes planted along the outbound MBTA tracks on Commonwealth ave (between leamington and wallingford) block view of the oncoming traffic and bikes for anyone turning Left from Comm Ave onto Wallingford
There is always at least one double parked on Cambridge St. between Joy St and Hancock. I don't know if it's for the restaurant, the gym or what but no double parking should be better enforced here.
Drivers ignore the red light here, as if it were a right on red
This is SUPPOSED to be a dedicated bike & bus lane. But drivers routinely ignore this designation and use the lane to get ahead of the gridlock.  It needs separation and/or enforcement.
Many people use the Locks to get from Boston to Charlestown or Cambridge, but they are very narrow. The walkways need to be wider, and ideally accommodate people riding bikes.

Pavement in the bike lane is in extremely poor condition. potholes and 3 inch wide ruts parallel to the direction of travel. The only way to safely commute in this section of road by bike is to take the main travel lane.

Very dangerous to cross this bridge by bike. You can't take the sidewalk because it ends in stairs. Shoulder is not wide enough to bike in safely. Taking the full lane results in angry drivers, yelling, honking, unsafe passing, dangerous harassment.
Cars are allowed to turn right from Staniford onto Merrimac so no safe time for pedestrians to cross, even when they have the pedestrian light.
Long wait for walk signal

The timing of the light cycle is not well synced- and pedestrians have the walk signal while drivers are still going through the intersection. The construction in the area has been going on for months and the sidewalks are a mess.

Large Potholes on a big downward-sloped street that bikers routinely go down very fast on. With the green line, buses, and traffic, this is a disaster area if someone biking hits a hold and loses control.
People park too close to the driveway on the even side, blocking trucks from entering the driveway. This backs up traffic and worsens when drivers take to the sidewalks.
Parked cars cross and block sidewalk forcing pedestrians into the street.

When crossing on the east bound side of the street, cars do not pay attention to the pedestrian walk signal and they do not yield to pedestrians.  Often cars will beep loudly at the pedestrians crossing
This intersection needs stop signs on Dorchester Ave as they speed and do not yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk.
There are multiple large/deep potholes on the BU bridge.

I have had several occasions when riding my bike on Summer Street, where I was FORCED onto Melcher or else be hit by a right turning car or truck. Need traffic calming and better visibility for bikes going straight.
Plenty of width on the road for a cycletrack. A parking-separated cycletrack would make perfect sense here.
Current Sull. Statn. bike racks/lean-to exposed to the elements & require crossing lanes of bus traffic to access.  It's too far from the station for informal security...
There are no sidewalks on this side of the street and there are no walk signals or streetlights for pedestrians here.
Drivers often don't yield to pedestrians in the unsignalized crosswalk across Harvard Ave.
Parking cars cross and block sidewalk forcing pedestrians into the street.
Constant speeding on Condor Street at night.
the road is very narrow, therefore slowing down traffic in the morning and making it even more difficult when construction on adjacent buildings is underway.
There are no stop signs at the corners and people speed down this street. It makes it very difficult to cross as a pedestrian
The speed limit on this road is 30 however as a resident of this area I know that folks are consistently speeding down the hill and up over a rise in the road and visibility is limited.
There are no sidewalks on either side of the street causing you to have to walk in the street.
I commute every day up and down Comm Ave and the intersection of Comm Ave and St. Paul St is one where I see cars running red lights more times than not.
The Pleasant St road is in poor condition!
There is no stop sign here and too many times I see people flying down this hill and not yielding to people traveling straight on Comm Ave
People park really close to pretty much every intersection. I know parking is limited, but, still.

Cars traveling eastbound on carriage lane are legally only allowed to make a left turn onto Warren St. but turn illegally right to merge onto eastbound Commonwealth Ave.  Pedestrians and traffic aren't expecting the cars

Are there actually two lanes of traffic on South Street? Traffic patterns fill up the equivalent of two lanes, but this makes a dangerous situation with cars trying to turn left and blocking the intersection.
People cross at the eastern end of the inbound Washington St. T stop instead of walking to the crosswalk at Washington St.
Cars cutting through from Chestnut Hill to Commonwealth Ave  speed around this curve.  It's a blind curve and dangerous for all the pedestrians in the area, especially elderly
Blind curve with parking area nearby
Lots of people speed around this blind curve, can't see pedestrians and people getting out of their cars parked on Wallingford
Pedestrians cross to/from the post office without walking to a crosswalk

Lack of parking enforcement in area. Cars parked too close to alley driveway by 100 Condor makes it difficult for 18-wheelers to turn down it. Causes major back-ups and chaos, like people driving on sidewalks to get around.
Lack of parking enforcement in area. Cars park within in a couple feet of this hydrant constantly. This would be a ticketable offense in any other part of the city.
I have almost been hit while biking on Commonwealth avenue many times. Today I was hit by a car crossing the bike lane trying to park. The bike lane needs to be protected.
Little thing can mean more use of bike helmets: helmets sold must have way to pass part of uLock thru helmet so u can lock it up with your bike instead of have to lug helmet around with u.

There are always vehicles parked or using Winter Street all day. Please enforce a time limit for commercial vehicles, for example between 8 PM and 8 AM. Other cities do this successfully, why is it so hard for us to do it?

Last summer the gas company ripped up portions of Market St including the bike lanes and the bike boxes at Market St and Arlington St. The bike box on the northbound side of Market St was not repainted & motorists do not recognize it as a bike box.
I bike home at night on this bike path and the street lights more often then not are not on. I suspect the bulbs are burnt out or they are not properly programmed to switch on when it is dark.

location: \The bike lane heading into boston has a large lump of concrete in the middle
COMMENTS: ~6\"\" high. I have seen a cyclist flip his bike over it"
The road surface over the rails is extremely jarring to bicyclists riding with traffic, and even worse in the pedestrian area-- it trips pedestrians and would be hard on a wheelchair.
After the gas company ripped up Market St last summer, they did not fully repaint the bike lane. There is just one painted white line, with no bike symbols on it. It is not obviously a bike lane.

These are the least respected bike lanes I have observed anywhere in Boston. Despite the painted bike lanes and signs that say 'no stopping any time', motor vehicles and delivery trucks constantly stop in these bike lanes.

The green bike lane here invites cars bearing right to cream cyclists bearing left. It should be replaced with infrastructure encouraging cyclists bearing left to take the lane prior to the intersection.

The cars have a stop light but the pedestrians only have a painted crosswalk, no signal across Roslin. But there is a button and signal across Washington. Confusing to pedestrians. Cars don't yield to pedestrians. Lots of school kids around here.
Peabody Square is not pedestrian friendly. It takes too long to cross 3 sidewalks from T station to Talbot at Boston Housing authority building because each crosswalk is on a different cycle.
Crossing guard needed for school kids 8am-9:30 and 4PM-5:30
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.

This is a major bike thoroughfare but also frequented by 18 wheelers. With no protection for bikes that makes it really dangerous for cyclists.
This is a major bike thoroughfare but also frequented by 18 wheelers. With no protection for bikes that makes it really dangerous for cyclists.
The construction here squeezes bikes into the middle of traffic. All construction in Boston needs to consider cyclist safety when narrowing roadways.
A designated bike lane simply ends at this intersection, forcing cyclists to awkwardly merge with motor vehicles, a dangerous situation for cyclists.
We need a crosswalk here for all the school kids. It is very dangerous and people prefer to cross here because Codman Square has too much wait time for walk light.
NO curb cuts to this important pedestrian way
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.
Really dangerous crossing for bikes. Too many lanes and cars moving too fast.
Between Commuter rail and Cass this roadway is a mess from large trucks! Huge potholes and other surface issues.
Charles Circle is a death trap for pedestrians.
Crosswalks are needed here.
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.
This is a major bike thoroughfare but also frequented by 18 wheelers. With no protection for bikes that makes it really dangerous for cyclists.
The fact that one of the major bike routes of the city doesn't connect here is a major issue. Please force DCR to fix it.
Between Commuter rail and Cass this roadway is a mess from large trucks! Huge potholes and other surface issues.
Put a Hubway here. All the tourists will use it.

The multi-way stops in this area make crossing streets nearly impossible as people do not pay attention to pedestrians nor do they obey the stop signs and there are no lights to better regulate this area.
School bus often parked here. Too wide and partially blocks lane.
Parked cars combined with curve heading north makes it difficult to see hazards ahead.
Construction to gas lines a fews weeks ago left road surface a mess
Too narrow to be a 2 way street, especially with school buses and parking on both sides.
Need bike lane or cycle track. Too narrow and unsafe for bikers.
Cars don't yield to pedestrians, even a whole group of school kids. Please more pedestrian warning signs and traffic calming.

Vehicles turning from St. James onto Dartmouth do not slow down. Throughout the pedestrian crossing light, vehicles weave between pedestrians. I feel safer crossing mid-block than to attempt to cross at this intersection during the pedestrian light

Vehicles turning from Boylston onto Dartmouth do not slow down. Throughout the pedestrian crossing light, vehicles weave between pedestrians. I feel safer crossing mid-block than to attempt to cross at this intersection during the pedestrian light.
Traffic that is outbound on Huntington uses this corner to reverse direction during the pedestrian light.

Vehicles turning from Arlington onto Tremont do not slow down. Throughout the pedestrian crossing light, vehicles weave between pedestrians. I feel safer crossing mid-block than to attempt to cross at this intersection during the pedestrian light.
People park on both sides of the street in the no parking area making it impossible for emergency vehicles to get through.  More parking enforcement is needed.
In the afternoon, the stop light here is wonderfully backlit by the sun. Which means I might be blinding myself checking whether the light has turned green.

The road splits here into 3 lanes. Drivers going on Cambridge use the left-lane to go straight, and impatient drivers speed through the center lane to cut those who've been waiting off. Which pisses people off, and forces a merge on the other side.

This path is great during the day for a walker to get from Wiltshire Road to Foster St. However there really needs to be more lighting put up. When it comes to safety this shortcut needs better lighting at night.

We have sabbath observant citizens in this area. From Friday to Saturday they can not push the button since it is against our religion to use electricity. On Friday and Saturday the walk sign should be put on a timer or a crossing guard available.
\Cars don't yield to pedestrians trying to cross to go to the synagogue
column7: often speeding up when ppl are in/at the intersection.  A \"\"State Law - Stop for Pedestrians in Crosswalk\"\" thing in the middle of the street might help.\""

COMMENTS: Received a death threat from angry driver who refused to yield to me while in crosswalk.
People rarely yield to people in crosswalk. This is a school zone too.

Vehicles turning from Columbus onto Dartmouth do not slow down. Throughout the pedestrian crossing light, vehicles weave between pedestrians. I feel safer crossing mid-block than to attempt to cross at this intersection during the pedestrian light.

There are no crosswalks at this intersection.  Many people cross from Gladstone St onto Walley to walk down to the Suffolk Downs T stop.  This is a blind curve and highly trafficked by cars; without a crosswalk here it is unsafe.

There really needs to be a cross walk here to get the synagogue / school.  Otherwise you have to go way out of your way to find one and that does not work when you have children or they need to go to the bathroom.

Nobody who comes up Foster St. stops or even slows prior to the crosswalk... I myself have almost been hit as a pedestrian and I have also seen many people almost get hit by speeding cars who fail to slow down or stop at this intersection.

The road is in terrible shape all along here. I'm hoping/assuming it will all be repaved when the forest hills project is finished? and maybe bikes will have their own route and not have to ride on it?
Bicyclists run the red light and weave through the pedestrian traffic.
Vehicles make turns without slowing and without looking, including during the pedestrian crossing lights.
People speed and do not honor the stop sign.
Vehicle traffic speeds down Beacon St.
People make illegal left turns from Commonwealth Ave (eastbound) onto Washington St and nearly hit pedestrians crossing Washington St.
no warning that two lanes merge as they turn the corner

Vehicles turning from Boylston onto Exeter do not slow down. Throughout the pedestrian crossing light, vehicles weave between pedestrians. I feel safer crossing mid-block than to attempt to cross at this intersection during the pedestrian light.

Cars come quickly from both directions on Corey Road, coming uphill and around curves.  Crossing from Evans to Cummings , walking or driving (even worse) is frightening.  A number of years ago a child was killed here.  This crossing needs a light.
left turn onto the arborway is a challenge, oncoming traffic, cars stuck in the intersection, no pedestrian visibility, nothing works in this mess right now!
Rare is it for drivers to yield for pedestrians in the crosswalk.

Basically, the easiest way to get across chestnut hill is to go over that little island, and people do that all the time, but  there's no crosswalk or stop sign and cars that are unfamiliar with this practice don't slow down when people approach.
Large holes in the sidewalk between sunset cantina and cvs. Elderly people or handicap people at risk of injury.
Potholes/uneven road surface due to past construction.
Bikers go straight on comm ave while cars turn to go onto storrow drive. Difficult to see the bikers sometimes at night, and large volume of cars and bikers around 9 when night class gets out.
Pat the Cat is not impressed with the lack of concern motor vehicle drivers show towards bicyclists at this intersection.
Need more enforcement for people to stay out of the bike lane. I bike here every morning and every morning there is a truck/car/bus parked in the bike lane.
The  sidewalks and roads around this hospital is a death trap
The walk signal runs at the same time as traffic from Agganis Way & Pleasant Street, so cars are constantly turning into pedestrians with right of way. Very dangerous intersection.

Can we please have a median at the Purchase Street off-ramp intersection with Oliver/Seaport? People are constantly shifting lanes at the last minute which causes gridlock and makes turning onto Seaport very unpredictable.
The Bike lanes here are full of potholes and re-sealed asphalt. The cuts in the road that were resealed cover up the bike lane markers and make it hard to see the bike lane.
Horrible road conditions make it dangerous to bike and drive here. This is a disaster waiting to happen, as someone biking could hit a pothole and fall into traffic.
Silver line bus drivers think they don't have to yield to pedestrians crossing the crosswalk. Or maybe it's just one crazy bus driver who keeps doing it.

There are no crosswalks on Medford St. from Main St until you reach the high school.  Cars speed down Medford St. There is a park and a Harborwalk entrance that elicit a lot of foot traffic.  This is a dangerous area.
Crosswalks needed along this area of Medford St!!!!!
Walk light strands pedestrians on traffic island because cycle favors south-to-north over north-to-south crossing
Blaine Street empties into a private parking lot. Drivers speed through this parking lot endangering handicapped persons & childern. Dead End street 10+ years ago. Needs to be re-instated as such.
Motorists IGNORE crosswalk all the time. Still as dangerous as it was before crosswalk installed with flashing lights.

Cambridge Street narrows from 3 lanes to 1 here. Motorists insist on getting through the light first, causing cars to block crosswalks. Pedestrians at risk when traffic moves, cars ignore  pedestrians
Cars coming over the hill on Canterbury Street speed into a right turn onto Seymour Street, but cannot see pedestrians in the middle of crossing.  Too many near misses.

There are increasing numbers of commercial vehicles using both Jamaicaway and Storrow Drive driving over the lines and taking up more than one lane and switching lanes without signaling. This is very dangerous for many reasons.
Large new Dr's office here, people need to get to bus stop on other side, no crossing light @ Birmingham parkway, needs crosswalk or pedestrian light desparately

Had very close call today. Car suddenly parks illegally in bike lane and passenger opens door right in front of me! Please install protected bike lane immediately! Bike lane is nothing more than extra parking for cars and police refuse to cite them.

Please put bumps back here, the cobblestone do NOTHING to slow people! Someone is going to be killed because people go TWICE the speed limit constantly. Though before and after work is the worse it is constant!!!
Constant double parking in bicycle lane. Forces bicyclist into busy street. NOT SAFE!
\wait \"\"forever\"\" walklight.\""
The Boston College shuttle buses travel at least TWICE the speed limit on off hours!!

Exiting the driveway for the day care at the community center there is a blind spot because of the 1 street parking spot. There should not be a parking spot on the edge of the day care driveway. Accidents happen.

crosswalk and lane markings are not maintained,  A vehicle which stops for a pedestrian frequently is passed at HIGH speed by another because there is room for multiple lanes.  A median refuge island AND warning signs would keep traffic in one lane.

During the walk phase a major compeating vehicular movemend is northbound out of shirley street, bearing right across the crosswalk then bearing left into Newmarket.  Is this diagonal crosswalk here just because there are conduits to these corners?
The crosswalks and lights to make crossings to this corner suck! Light takes forever, Markings and warning signs are invisible and it is like crossing a football field of pavement.
This cross-walk signal NEVER happens!  WTF
Private ROW from here to southwest needs sidewalks on both sides.
Is the parking lot realy the bike path?  The transitions are a little tricky.
It is difficult to tell when a vehicle will yield to let you cross the slip lane.  Need way to make sure this turn is made at a slow speed.
Monumental BUMP in sidewalk!  not been touched for 30 years.

When commuters drive up St. Theresa's Ave, they do NOT stop at the STOP sign prior to turning left onto Howitt Road.  The signage is dangling up high on a telephone pole.  We were informed that a new STOP sign would be placed at that location.
Speeding up St. Theresa's Ave and not Stopping at Howitt Road
When approaching Brooks Street from Olivia Road, cars are usually parked on Brooks St right up to the corner of Olivia Road.  This makes it impossible to check for oncoming traffic on Brooks St.
It is extremely hard to see oncoming traffic (going very fast) if you are trying to make a left turn from melrose onto Arlington.
Nobody respects the sidewalks in this area
There is no traffic guidance for an increasingly busy intersection at whole foods.  This is not safe for car traffic and also not safe for those walking.   There needs to be a traffic light.

People are cutting out of the back of the MGH T stop and are not using the crosswalk. The curve in the road here as well as the amount of pedestrian and car traffic makes it very dangerous for people to cross here.
When crossing Beacon Street on Chestnut Hill Avenue on the east side of the road (by the C line tracks), there is only enough time allotted by the lights to cross one half of the road.

There is not enough space on the sidewalk to walk with a stroller. And there needs to be a ramp on Harrison end of the street. You have to go up onto the sidewalk, down off the sidewalk and up onto the sidewalk to only then have to walk in the st

This is a very challenging left turn from Walnut onto Beacon St.  There is often constant traffic flow on Beacon (often at high speeds), combined with pedestrians and low visibility because of parked cars on Beacon.  Consider adding a stop light.
The sidewalks are not wide enough at many points along melrose to walk with a stroller.  Therefore you have to walk in the street towards oncoming traffic.

Early Morning blinking traffic Lights make it very difficult to cross Hyde Park Ave. Traffic speeds through intersection and do not yield to pedestrians. Lights should be adjusted to return to normal operation at 5AM rather than 6AM at present.
\Cars keep speeding on Forest Hills St
column7: and the one-way \"\"cut-throughs\"\" of Williams"

COMMENTS: The nightly organized racing along American Legion is dangerous to drivers and pedestrians and the noise it generates is highly disturbing to residents, particularly when they are trying to sleep.

Commuters cut down the carriage lane on weekday mornings.  As this is going downhill, many of these drivers speed and there have been innumerable near-misses with children, bikers, runners, etc. There is no speed limit sign let alone speed bumps.

The existing bike lanes along the length of American Legion Hwy are unsafe for biking. The painted bike lines are faded and at points become public parking, suddenly forcing bike riders out into thick and fast moving traffic.

Dirvers on the Milton bound side of Dorchester Ave do not yield the right of way to Boston Bound drivers or Pedestrians.  The best fix for this problem is to allow an all way Pedestrian crossing while all drivers in all directions wait on Red Lights.

There has been a pedestrian death crossing the street between Cabot Estate and Jamaica Pond. There is no traffic signal at the Cabot entrance. Cars drive too fast and because the street curves there is poor visibility.
The walk signal takes a very long time to show up to cross and when it does it's only for like 15 seconds
Honking has gotten out of control.  Also people drive too fast down tremont and the cross walks are missing their signs
A two way cycle track would be very useful here.
The lanes aren't marked or are very poorly marked here. It is impossible to know where one is supposed to be.
Drivers go way too fast here and usually don't yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk here.
When coming E on Comm Ave, there's no safe way to turn L on the BU Bridge. There's not enough room on the opposite sidewalk/road for multiple cyclists to wait for the light to cross Comm Ave.
There is no crosswalk across Washington St at Rutland St.
This should be a no turn on red from Washington St to Court St. Cars making left on red frequently obstruct the crosswalk on Washington St.
The wait here is way too long to walk. Pedestrian traffic here is much heavier than auto traffic and should have priority. This intersection also needs to be redesigned to require hard left turns.
Left turning cars frequently fail to yield at the red light. This type of offramp design, seen here and at Dartmouth and Huntington has no place in a crowded and busy city.
Cars backed up frequently block this intersection.
There should be crosswalks to cross Washington from both sides of E/W Concord St
Many drivers don't yield when making illegal right turns on red.

This intersection needs singalization for bikes turning right. They have to merge into cars also turning right into a poorly makred bike lane and it causes confusion. Letting bikes go a few seconds earlier would help.

It is really awkward to get to the northbound side of park drive from the muddy river path on a bike, or walking. There is a curb cut to allow it, but it is uncomfortable and cars aren't always looking for you
Very difficult to get cars to yield to people in crosswalk!
There is no sensible way to negotiate this intersection coming down Parsons St. towards Greenough Blvd.
There should be crosswalks to cross Washington St on both sides of W. & E. Springfield Sts.
Sidewalks are frequently blocked by people parking in the adjacent lot pulling up and parking on the sidewalk. There should be a fence or barrier between the sidewalk and lot.
There is a new left turn only light from Tremont onto School St that drivers always ignore. A No Turn On Red sign should be posted here.

Harrison westbound goes from 2 driving lanes to 1 here with no warning. Rt. lane should be turn-only onto Berkeley, leaving left lane to continue on Harrison. Current situation causes argument about which lane has right of way to cross intersection.

This bike lane along the south side of comm ave from knemore sq to charlesgate should be totally removed or totally redone. It is 100% ineffective in its current configuration. Way too narrow, cars go way too fast, too much double parking.
Drivers regularly barrel through this crosswalk while pedestrians are about to cross.  I don't know if they can't see the crosswalk or simply ignore it.
Drivers regularly barrel through this crosswalk while pedestrians are about to cross.  I don't know if they can't see the crosswalk or simply ignore it.
MBTA posted it's bus stop signs 100' north of intersection, which allows vehicles to park very close to intersection blocking their view of traffic proceeding southerly.
Very loud and aggressive dirt bike riders in this area, especially Thursday- Sunday nights. They are doing dangerous tricks and putting everyone at risk, let alone the noise level is unbearable.
There are no bike lanes, and cars turn quickly off Sigourney
Trucks almost strike bikers often because they are trying to get through quickly, and there is ZERO bike infrastructure.
Greet street sidewalks are poorly maintained, and often have obstructive debris.
We really need bike infrastructure here. .
There are visibility problems at night.  The area is very poorly lit.
Need to wait for a long time for the light and cars run red lights anyway.
Drivers ignore the crosswalk.
This intersection need a do not block intersection because cars during the rush hours block it all the time
Due to the presence of a city double-wide solar trash-can/advertising substrate the walk-button is not accessible on this corner.
The cycle is sooooooo long that the cars on Calumet Street begin to J-Drive just before its their turn!
How about a ramp to flank this set of stairs and make the park accessible to the station?

Drivers just ignore the traffic lights and go over the crosswalk, although pedestrians have the right of way. The only reason why there haven't been a ton of crashes already is because pedestrians watch out for reckless drivers.
People get anxious to turn onto Cheney and don't stop, or make aggressive turns.  This street is on a hill and visibility isn't great.

I've lived on Redlands Road for over 10 years and I see time and time again folks speeding right through the four way stop sign.  I'm not only concerned as I drive, but there are lots of foot traffic & I cringe each time I see it
Where Walnut and Crawford meet, there is no signage to indicate who has the right of way.  It seems like people on Crawford should yield to people coming along Walnut, but it is not clear.
School buses turning into the bus yard make their right turn from the center lane.
Cars coming out of Belvidere turning left on Mass Ave do not yield to pedestrians (who, admittedly, are crossing against the light, but still!)
It is very difficult to negotiate a left turn from Chaney onto Blue Hill Ave at the light here.  Traffic coming off Washington St blocks the intersection.

Big trucks always double park across from the Tavern. This blocks up the three lights behind it and causes lots of gridlock traffic. The bike lane being one of the car lanes makes it almost impossible to get through

It is a very small street that many drivers use to bypass the traffic light.  The road has several large potholes in it making it a hazzard for both cars and pedestriaans, since there is not enough room for sidewalks
The bike lane markings on the pavement have worn away and need to be repainted as soon as possible.

Timings on walk lights not accurate--causing people to ignore them, & guess as to how much time is really left--defeating the purpose of the system. Other cities have a countdown when it reaches zero it is at the time when cars can start across.

There is no ped phase in this light cycle, which would be okay if the call buttons worked.  I've had to wait more than a full light cycle (and this one is long) before getting a walk.  Leads to jaywalking at a location that is dangerous.
Lots of kids on this street, and it gets way more than its share of neighborhood traffic from the Highlsnd MBTA stop and the shopping center/Roche Bros.
Missing stop sign.

Walk cycle crossing VFW is not long enough to get across.  Turning cars from Independence do not stop for right on red; often do not see peds because they are watching traffic to their left.  Very dangerous.  One fatality several years ago.
Makes it difficult to travel up Broadway with multiple double cars parked

Trucks continually use the parkways in West Roxbury and Hyde Park. The signage is not enough. I know the State police patrol these parkways but we need to do something about the ever increasing use of trucks large and small on our parkways.
TRUCKS on the parkways, every day! Trucks ignore the small signs, state police are useless.
The road has gotten progressively worse since construction started on the street. Very hard on bike tires.
Tour buses/trolleys frequently pull out into traffic here without even looking to see if there is anyone in the bike lane. I have almost been hit several times.
Bikers don't stop at the red light and impede on pedestrian crossing.
People often cross away from the crosswalks here. Most of the time, they don't look before crossing in front of traffic.
This walk signal takes FOREVER. Very frustrating.

People go wrong way on one way street in morning. have almost been hit by drivers speeding on Chestnut first thing in morning when I walk my dog. 1 guy who drives a silver Prius that almost hit me,I told him it was a one way, he said I know. So?
Hi this is an all way stop, no one stops, ever, it's super dangerous to bicycle or walk here
Need to enforce â€œDonâ€™t Block the Boxâ€ especially during rush hour.
More than once, I have seen cars entering West Cedar Street from Cambridge Street even though this section is one-way in the opposite direction. Far better signage is needed here!

New walk sings were put up at Grove Street and it has become near-lethal to cross here since those signs let you cross when west-bound traffic on Cambridge Street also turns left into Grove Street (behind you if you are walking west-bound).
The sidewalks are too narrow to fit a stroller between the trees growing between the sidewalk and the curb on one side and the retaining walls people have built in their front yard on the other side.
Very confusing for drivers and pedestrians.
Very confusing for drivers and pedestrians.
Bicyclists ride on sidewalk, going the wrong way, despite lots of pedestrians.

There are multiple lanes of traffic doing different things and turning left onto Heath street is difficult/dangerous with the tracks.  Something like at Packard's corner: well marked bike lanes, and little rubber protectors on rails might help

The ped crossing call lights never worked right.  They will work promptly for the first side of the VFW crossed, but then not at all on the other side, leaving you stuck in the middle.  Drivers also often don't notice the red light at the crossing.
Heading south (away from the rotary), people treat this stretch of road before the light as two lanes-- based on road markings, it's not.

Here the bike like abruptly changes from the right of the right lane to the left of the left lane, creating a dangerous situation for bikers trying to cross traffic. Cars coming from the Mass Ave bypass also tend to speed.
It need to be parking spaces and also the location need to have a lot of space for a lot of people to vote and be able to leave right away after voting
Drivers come off Center Street, impatient w traffic, and roar up Greenough, especially during rush hours.
Cars speed down Corey Street going far beyond the 30 mph speed limit.
People continually run the stop sign, even when school buses are in the intersection dropping off kids.
Cycle is rediculously long, which results in schoolchildren jaywalking during rush hour. Someone may die.
During rush hour timer should be automatic and not be pushed, plenty of people walking to forest hills station.
Ticket the bastards.
Cars turning right from Massachusetts Ave onto Beacon street force bikes going straight and pedestrians crossing.

Drivers sometimes speed to make the turn before oncoming traffic arrives without watching for pedestrians.  I've seen a few close misses where turning cars nearly hit pedestrians who have the walk sign.
it is closed to new England  medical center ,the cars double parked  always block the ambulanceã€‚
they don't stop at stop sign!
People speed down Main St. and they don't stop for people in crosswalks. There are a lot of blind corners. A stop sign would be so helpful.
Cars turning left from the central lane, while the left lane lets you drive straight.
Very, very common during events at TD Garden. They just double park there even without emergency lights on and go to an event.

Northbound cars on Mass Ave often run red lights @ Belvidere. Pedestrians crossing Mass (even on WALK sign) risk being hit by cars running the light. Drivers see the lights @ Boylston but miss Belvidere light (less conspicuous).

Some people use Dwinell Street to avoid the stoplight at Corey and VFW Pkwy or as an alternate route to get to Weld Street which leads to them speeding to get ahead of the VFW traffic or simply because there's fewer cars on Dwinell.
Left turn (Centre->Allandale) supposed to be only on green arrow but this is frequently ignored, needs better signage.
REALLY NEEDS A PEDESTRIAN LIGHT. Scary to cross in the crosswalk (difficult to see, cars do not observe L turn light). Frequent pedestrian crossing away from the crosswalk bc actually seems safer.
bicyclists ride on the sidewalk, despite children, elderly and disabled.
The traffic is so bad that ambulances and fire engines cannot get through.

This is a very sharp turn with a narrow roadway and poor visibility.  Already very dangerous when biking.  But the pavement has been in atrocious condition for years, forcing cyclists to ride in the middle of an already dangerous road.
There is no easy, safe way for a bicyclist to make a left turn onto Seaport Blvd. Please install a protected intersection to complement the bike lane.

Too many coming down Park St. do not even slow down for the stop signs. There is no monitoring or enforcement in the neighborhood street and the culture is do whatever one pleases. This is hard to understand in a neighborhood filled with kids.
Turniing left off Appleton to Tremont, vision is blocked by vehicles parked in front of Masa.  Traffic traveling inbound tend to drive fast as well making the intersection dangerous for left turns.

Alley on Dartmouth end of footbridge over Storrow Dr. DANGEROUS!!!! I jog this area and have almost gotten hit-  Why so dangerous?: -you can't SEE cars, you don't EXPECT them (small alley) & you can't HEAR them! (Storrow noise)
Bike riders and skateboarders racing through Commons.  Seems workers use this to commute to City Hall and Financial District.
Lends itself to a lot of traffic and accidents

There is NO STOP SIGN EITHER DIRECTION creating many accidents or near misses.  People speed down Bunker Hill and hit cross-traffic going from School street to straight down Pearl street. This is worsened by poor visibility from parked cars.
Frequent speeding, clipping lane lines around corners along Allandale
There are four driveways, several side streets, and a fire station.  There needs to be a crosswalk by the entrance to Whole Foods.
cars zoom out of various driveways without looking for pedestrians on siidewakk

there should be go slow children signs on the section from northdale rd to fairlane rd around 17 new haven st there are small children there and the cars speed all day going by there its a accident waiting to happen

Taxis trying to get into the South Station taxi queue blow through this stop sign without looking. Also, Livery vehicles and private vehicles waiting to pick people up at South Station park in the intersection illegally.
hard for drivers on Lawrence to see pedestrians crossiny until they have just approached the crossing area. Also, hard for drivers turning onto Berkeley to see cars incoming on Berkeley.
People try to go straight down Porter St from the left lane which is a left turn only lane and then they nearly hit those crossing Porter St or Chelsea St when it's their turn to cross.
if you're trying to make a right onto Rt 1A, the visibility of people coming off the ramp is low, combined with the people driving down Havre St, it's a recipe for disaster.
Everyone who picks up food from Santarpio's double parks their car on Porter St.  It's dangerous and reduces visibility of walkers

People cross away from the crosswalks because there are inadequate crosswalks.  Cars do not yield for walkers in the square. The square is very confusing with each side being a one way and a lack of direction when you first approach the square.
this intersection is terrible, no one ever yields when turning and it's a block from the police station, ironically
people don't yield to crosswalks in the street here
people just turn here without a signal and do not yield to the cars going straight.
People speed down this street thinking they can get out to VFW. It's a street loaded with kids.
Also Sophia restaurant goers park here right where kids come to play ball. They also come out late night causing noise issues. Does Sophia's not have enough spots for its patrons?
This road should become a one-way street. It gets so packed during the rush hour that it takes forever for the residents to park/get out of the driveway.

The Emerald Necklace bike and walking trails end abruptly and there is no safe place to cross Route 9 and connect to the trails again. This requires crossing in the middle of the road in an unsafe area.

On this whole block, pedestrians wander across the street against the light, away from the crosswalks, and without regard to oncoming traffic.  There are also often crowds outside of the convenience store on the corner, spilling out into the street.
Once the walking sign turns to the red hand the countdown begins at 7. Once the 1 disappears the traffic light changes to green. The intersections at Cross/Hanover and Cross/Sudbury have lags.

New construction on Nearen Row in Charlestown. Nearen is one lane (narrow) st running Tremont down to Ferrin St--in that direction. residents of the new construction routinely drive wrong way on this one way st
This roadway was recently, within the past year dug up for consistent gas leak. The road surface is really bumpy and full of pot holes.
Even though there are crosswalks drivers don't yield to pedestrians

To get over to the Warren Street T-Stop people consistently cross at the break in the carriage lane and the main Comm Ave roadway. There is no safeway to cross and then they run towards the on-coming trains where its a very narrow sidewalk.
Even though there is a crosswalk, drivers don't yield to pedstrians
cars are incentivezed to speed without any expectation of bikes or pedestrians
Despite crosswalks, drivers don't yield to pedestrians
the hancock tower creates severe wind conditions that make it near impossible to stay on a bike.
cars do not stop to allow pedestrians to cross even though there is a crosswalk present.

Cars coming off of Cumberland Street to take a right on Huntington Avenue seldom yield to pedestrians. I saw a man in a wheelchair in front of me who was hesitant in crossing . Many cars run the light.

There's a utility box placed right next to a light pole which narrows the sidewalk to about 2-3 feet. This blocks the wheelchair access and obstructs pedestrian traffic. Can the box be moved a few feet away?

People heading west on Stuart Street run through the red light  and are typically traveling at fast speeds. They also jam the intersection when there is nowhere to go instead of yielding when the light is turning red holding up pedestrian traffic.
Many (>10) bicycles are left locked to trees, poles etc daily. Would it be possible top put a few bike parking stands on the north side of Blossom street? No bike facilities at all currently
People double park in front of the residential parking and in the residential parking preventing us residents from parking in our own neighborhood

roadway under mass ave1) paint lane dividers as most people drive down the middle 2) the potholes are fixed but when you hit the lowest point due to natural acceleration of the car going down hill you hit the uneven surfaces hard
People show no courtesy to side street traffic and it's impossible to turn left out from Billings to Spring
People block the roadway during high traffic times so it's hard to go straight to Gould or turn on to Spring from VA light
Please help keep cars from squeezing out bike riders!
Street is too wide, cars travel too fast
that people barrel into the rotary without pausing or yielding, all the time (also, nearby, the rotary at Holy Name Church) -- it's as if people just don't KNOW who has right-of-way

I have noticed that drivers do not abide by the stop signs at the intersection of 1st and and 13th street, and roll through the cross walk and/or fail to stop behind the stop line, making it dangerous for pedestrians.

The far light at inbound Comm. Avenue can change green before the light at outbound Comm. Avenue. it is then hard  to see that the near by light is still red. There are regular car accidents at Gloucester/Com Ave. outbound. check the stats.
Elderly from 80 Mason Street do not walk to Tremont to cross...they cross in the middle of the block.
Too many bikers, taxi and trucks using the Pedestrian Zone.
Right at the starbucks, people double park and block a lane of traffic

try walking from the theatre district to the other side of 95 - there are no sidewalk cuts or you have to weave back and forth, from one side of the street to the other to find one.  no baby carriage or wheelchair could possible navigate this.
Traffic lights are clearly not respected at this intersection

Traffic is very heavy on A street. Pedestrian crossing as well as vehicles entering A street both have a hard time. Poor visibility as parking along A St is right up to the intersection. It may be time to consider traffic lights.

People turning don't stop at the red light, or stop but farther from the line. it's dangerous for pedestrians crossing. A car stop right in front of me as I was crossing, thus blocking my path. I had to knock on the window to ask them to move back.
This turn is confusing to pedestrians and drivers. There is no light or sign indicating anyone has priority or should yield. Cars force pedestrians already crossing.
Some cars speed down Tremont.  Especially at times when there's low traffic, like in the early morning or late evening.

This intersection is outrageously dangerous. People in both directions try to turn without being to see if there is oncoming traffic. There are near collisions almost everyday. There need to be turn lanes at this intersection.

People run the light on Center street everyday at the Forbes intersection. Including a school bus that runs the light, that has been red for at least 10 seconds. It is a hazard for cars, pedestrians, bikes, walkers and kids.

There are groups of people wandering around this corner (Mass Ave & Albany St). Some of them look to be drug addicts. I also saw these people assaulting in this corner at least 3 times! This is a serious safety concern for resident who live near by

People are not supposed to park on the right hand side of the street in the AM. Cars park here all the time in the morning blocking traffic causing hazards to cars, walkers and cyclists. They sit in car to hold spot until the time has passed.
People always double park when getting take out

The cross button requires a wait that is excessive and at least two full cycles of traffic light changes before cross signal is displayed.  One push to walk button does not worked and is located in front of the jewelry repair store.
No Turn On Red sign is not large enough and is to far away for drivers to see when turning from Centre onto Willow for Roche Bros entrance. Drivers ignore sign.
Running red light is not uncommon here. If you stay for 20 mins here, you can observe a car or two running a red light.

location: \Cars sometimes \"\"free fall\"\" down this section of the street"

COMMENTS: There are cars parked along both sides of the street and the street doesn't seem wide enough for cars along both sides and a travel lane in the middle.
People turning right onto Corey towards Centre street often don't stop before turning.
Cars speed on this street from the stop sign at Lyall street until they get to Corey street.
People will typically roll through the stop sign on Dwinell at Lyall, if they actually stop at all.  I've seen people drive through without even slowing down.

This happens EVERYWHERE, in every part of the city. Put in red-light runner cameras and change driver behavior by having a real consequence for running red lights. I even see police cars running the light - they need to be role models.

There are too many j-walkers in this area, and they usually cross at the worst times possible (right into oncoming traffic). This needs to be corrected to prevent the inevitable pedestrian-automobile collision.

People don't know that Opera Place is a one-way and will drive the wrong way down it. One person clearly knew it was a one-way and elected to drive the wrong to get to the alley quicker to park his truck.

The walk light in the middle part of the crosswalk is red even when traffic is stopped and it is safe to cross. As a result, it takes two cycles to cross the street. Even worse, it encourages people to cross on the red
On the west side sidewalk there is a stamped metal utility access cover that is raised, causing me to trip and fall.
Winter maintenance of the walkways over Mass Ave bridge is awful. I am often forced into the road to walk since the snow isn't shoveled. Not so bad in 2016, but brutal in 2015.
The new timing is terrible.
The new crosswalk replaced the traffic lights. Cars are NOT yielding and will eventually kill someone.

In the early morning, the decision to rely on flashing yellow lights at the various intersections around Copley is a mistake. Drivers blow through the intersections like they have a green, not even slowing down, and certainly never stopping.

The students cross from the college to their dorms across the street, the sidewalks are too far down and up the road, and cars speed on that long and straight piece of the street. Very dangerous for the students!
Despite the installation of flashing light activated by pedestrians, too many car still don't stop at the crossing
Despite the installation of flashing light activated by pedestrians, too many car still don't stop at the crossing. The same issue with car turning from either direction onto Louis Pasteur Avenue.
the wait for the walk is very long so people run across during breaks in traffic, dangerous
People routinely run red lights on Brookline crossing over the riverway. I've almost been hit by cars running reds twice. Not fun.
Often people do not stop at the light and speed.
I live on this street, people speed down this narrow one-way street street that cars park on both sides and kids play in the street.
Almost run over in the crosswalk by an Uber driver who made a LEFT turn onto Clarendon (wrong way) from Lawrence street. He was looking down at his app and not paying attention.

ThestretchofCausewayStreetfromN.WashingtonSttoStaniford Sthasbeenalivingnightmareforthelast18months.From concretebarriers,toblockedsidewalkstoconstantstreets beingdugup,patched,anddugupagain.AddillegalvehiclesparkedwheneverthereisaGardenevent
Cars/limos parked on the sidewalk.

Broadway Bridge is wide & off highway ramps. Vehicles speed over. Key connection for bikes (& everyone) to get back into Southie fr much of city. W.Broadway is wide enough for bike lanes  all the way across this bridge down to at least E.Broadway.

This intersection is dangerous. Cars don't follow the lane markings (ie go straight while in turn lane) so it's nearly impossible to safely position yourself on a bike. In a car, people are trying to move over/it's unclear where people are going.
It's terrifying to walk over here. It seems like it's impossible to get the cars to stop stop, even at the crosswalks.
cars coming around the corner of this wide one street are speeding and not visible for persons on the crosswalk

as you come off the bike path, it's unclear how to get across to continue south on Washington, and cars turn right into your path as you try to cross west with traffic to position yourself to go south with traffic.
This intersection is very confusing.
people walking go against the light because we have to wait too long
Getting from the T stop to the pedestrian bridge/esplanade takes 3 light cycles.
I will be coming down to the intersection along Belgrade, and cars who would/should yield to a car going straight, will turn in front of me, or alongside me.

This is a crosswalk by a school, and there is no curb-cut to the sidewalk at the North end. I can't easily get up or down with a trailer, or child on the back of the bike. This would be an issue for anyone in a wheelchair too.
So many issues..The main ones are the lane lines are doubled and confusing, and the parking is unnecessary and creates a hazard for bikes(dooring, bumping out into traffic)
They roll into the crosswalk and block bike's or pedestrian's way across.
They roll into the crosswalk and block bike's or pedestrian's way across.
Turning left onto Huntington from Francis is very hard. Oncoming traffic comes too far into the box. Back up traffic all the way on Francis to the hospital. Extremely painful!

This crosswalk has no light going from Landseer across to Gotmleys Funeral Home or vice versa. It's four lanes of traffic and often a first car will stop and the second will blow past. It's dangerous for pedestrians

Traffic lights and walk signs are too small, so people assume it is safe to walk across the intersection when car traffic has the right-of-way. Often I have to wait at a green light because of pedestrian traffic.
The light is too quick to allow for people turning left off Centre on to Corey due to the double lanes of traffic
There is no safe biking along route 9 here or safe way to cross route 9 on a bike or as a pedestrian.

As a resident, cars drive WAY TOO FAST on this winding street.  People drive down the middle of the road because of the bend in the road. There are children and elderly that live on this street. I don not feel safe.
This is an issue all along Comm Ave in this area but especially here. Cyclists do not adhere to traffic signals and frequently run reds.
there should be more access points to get to the esplanade.  remove storrow drive and reconnect the charles to back bay
reconnect the charles river to beacon hill, we want to access the park!  this is especially difficult for people with mobility issues.
Very dangerous rotary. Try to avoid at all costs due to safety but it's necessary to take, needs to be redesigned
I often have to wait at crosswalk for traffic to clear before crossing when walking my dogs.
Bicyclists ride on the sidewalk and make it very dangerous for pedestrians.
Bicyclists walk on the sidewalk, making it very dangerous for pedestrians.

There are two pedestrian lights that are not synced up to where there an endless wait. Leading to people crossing whenever possible.
People speed on Charter Street. It can get very dangerous. I would like to see speed bumps installed onto Charter as I don't see any real deterrent...There is even a grade school on Charter....

the drainage is terrible on the streets so there are enormous puddles after every rain storm.
Drivers heading northwest on Main Street towards Sullivan square routinely run this light. It is extremely dangerous.
Heading westbound on Beacon, the rightmost lane at Mass. Ave. is turn-only, but it is common for people to use this as a straight lane, even though there is no lane for them to continue into.

People are constantly running this red light when traveling northbound on N Washington st. Either they are interpreting the green turn arrow as an all green or they are taking an illegal right turn 200 feet past the light.
Drivers often speed and think they can turn left on red lights.
During Rush hour it would help if there were a police officer visible as many people try to rush the lights and end up blocking the intersection in Leverett Circle
the traffic lights should be ON by morning rush hour, not just flashing red and yellow. someday some car will be run over by the T.

Joy Street needs to be repaved.  There was gas utility work for several years.  The work was finally completed in the winter.   The street was torn up and is a bumpy and unsightly patch work now.  Please repave.  Thank you.

The intersection of the MBTA Charles St Station and the Liberty Hotel.MGH - the walk light isn't in sync with the traffic light of cars coming off of Charles St going towards RT 93 so the walk light is much too short - it could be longer.
The road widens encouraging cars to speed.  Crossing is perilous due to the extra wide street.
The road needs to be resurfaced due to multiple craters. The 2 lanes need to be clearly identified as people who go straight use the right lane that is only meant for right turns.

It is really dangerous during rush hour along this stretch of Comm Ave because DOUBLE PARKERS ROUTINELY PARK IN THE BIKES, the sidewalks are too busy for bikes and the traffic is very congested/aggressive.  NEED TO TICKET

This is a school zone and yet people ignore the flashing lights and speed across area or do not yield when kids are crossing. We need a crossing guard between 7am - 7:30am and 3:45 - 4:15 pm to ensure student safety in this intersection.
\Cars will try to use Newmarket to \"\"cut through\"\" traffic- I was nearly killed by an elderly driver who didn't even bother to slow down or look for pedestrians.  There are many in this area.\""
This stretch is particularly prone to drivers drifting into the bicycle lane. Please install flex posts or pylons for protection. This is a safety issue.
Bicycles have absolutely no protection from cars on this street. Please install a buffered protected bicycle lane for safe travel along this major bicycle route.
Drivers do illegal u-turns around the traffic island in this intersection- going the wrong way to get back onto Evans way in reverse direction.
It's hard to see cars coming around the corner because of parked cars. Would be good to have a mirror on the wall to see oncoming traffic.
Cars speed through lights getting off of Melnea Cass Blvd to Mass Ave or vice versa.  Surprised I'm still alive.
people run reds here on the right head turn all the time, in part leading to incidents like the crash off the bridge
As we exit our condo driveway at 342 Bunker Hill St it is very difficult to see the ongoing cars because parked cars near the driveway totally block the visibility and we can't see oncoming cars.

\And it also doesn't last long enough to cross all lanes of traffic

People cut through our street and speed.  Dangerous for lots of kids and dogs on this street.    And for people puling out of driveways and parking spots...

People regularly park facing the wrong direction- which makes it look like a one way street and people operate their vehicles accordingly.  Almost got in an accident because someone passed me on the left when I was making a left turn onto Zamora.

Bikers do not stop for the red lights, and often almost hit me as a pedestrian. One time the biker yelled at me for crossing when I had a pedestrian green light! Tickets should be issued to bikers who do not stop.

This is a tremendously dangerous, confusing and risky turn for  bicyclists. I encourage City councilors to ride through this intersection just once.

3 lanes at 899 Beacon St at Park Dr- left lane on Beacon for left turn only. Very small sign, no markings on street. Many cars in left lane go straight squeezing other 2 lanes with cars AND bikers.  HEAVY TRAFFIC-VERY DANGEROUS.  See this daily

When the Walk sign eventually turns on, only a cheetah could make it across four lanes of traffic in the time this signal gives.  This needs to be retimed badly.

Walkers, runners, moms  with strollers, young children, cyclists etc cross BACK STREET AT DARTMOUTH to the Dartmouth Overpass to the ESPLANADE. Add STOP SIGN, and a PEDESTRIAN WALKWAYs.  Cars Speed & there is NO VISIBILITY for pedestrians.  TKS!!!!

cars are crossing even though it is red light. This occurs very very frequently. Also, I see that cars stop in the middle of crosswalk almost every time. I also hear too much vehicle horn. On weekends, people yell each other or fight.

this alley is often blocked by a big pile of trash on trash day

Bicyclists ignore traffic rules by blocking the crossing lane, going through red lights, etc. When police are stationed here, they don't enforce the traffic laws on the bicyclists.
DRAG RACING!!!

If City of Boston leaves Beacon St as a three-lane speedway, then it shares responsibility for yesterday's crash.

People riding bikes on Cambridge and Joy continually and consistently ignore the red lights, and walk signs and the one way direction on Joy st
frequent accident (note the sections of missing/damaged cast iron fencing). Area needs traffic calming solutions. Accidents not reported in crash data????

Too many intersections have stop signs with a purpose, seemingly, to get people to slow down. The problem is drivers roll through or ignore these signs. As a result there's been an increase in drivers ignoring the necessary stop signs.

In front of convenience store, all the time.  Hubway station right here too, very bad for the bikers.

Drivers coming onto mass pike do not yield to those already on even though there is a yield sign

Adding a voice to the chorus who feel the separated bike lane to the RIGHT of the turn lane is extremely dangerous. Cars turning right cross in front of bikes, forcing them off the road or into a collision. I've had several close calls.
Boston should install red light cameras throughout the city. The amount of people who run lights and then speed are inexcusable. LA, DC and NYC have these ticketing cameras, why doesn't Boston.

Because of the not-so-practical one-way streets loop in the area, people ignore the one-way street and drive the wrong direction.

People just walk out into traffic getting to and from the bus stop here.  Traffic gets majorly disrupted in an already crowded area.

The lights are very short and combined with the problem of people not yielding when turning, it can be very dangerous to try and cross!!

nobody stops for pedestrians at this crosswalk
nobody stops for pedestrians at this crosswalk

signs to not block the intersection are needed.   Cars can be back to Buttonwood and I can't get across from lower to upper Buttonwood.

It would be nice to have a pedestrian traffic signal just like any other school zones. Sometimes they do have a cross guard but it varies. i also have a handicapped brother who cars see in the wheelchair and still speed on by.

Drivers going to route 99 cross over in FRONT of cars continuing in rotary. Very dangerous.
At the Chinese supermarket on Lincoln St. before the lights at Essex, many Chinese double park as they wait for passenger to grocery shop so Lincoln St becomes one lane. Congested & dangerous.

Pedestrians feel entitled and cross all over Cleary Square. They jump out into traffic even when they have the RED light  Pedestrians need to learn that they must follow stop lights just like cars do.Jaywalking is dangerous!
Many students and YMCA members cross Centre Street here and it takes forever for the walk light, so everyone tries to run between fast moving traffic
About 50% of drivers cruise through this stop sign
