Because people who go into the River Street convenience store park too close to HIllis Rd making it next to impossible to see who's coming down River St. Even if you pull out slowly people zoom down River and there have been so many near misses.
Drivers speeding up and down Roslin Street which is a danger to pedestrians, young children and other drivers in the area.
No enforcement within a block of the police station!  Please start ticketing and let customers know where alternative parking is available

In Hyde Park in general, people run stop signs all of the time.  I've never lived anywhere where I've seen this happen so often.Sometimes drivers look to see if the other driver is stopping at a four-way stop, then they step on the gas.

i walk here every day and cross Congress Street.  during rush hour people run red lights.  Yesterday, a large box truck ran red light and almost hit pedestrians in the crosswalk. you need to start writing tickets before someone dies.
From Temple to Boylston drivers double park on Tremont, especially around Loews Cinema causing tremendous congestion and danger. Cops are never there to move them.

It is very difficult to see pedestrians while driving because police cars are parked too close to the crosswalk areas. Additionally, it is difficult to see cars as a pedestrian from the sidewalk. Cars here should be parked elsewhere.
There is a bus stop directly across Bickford ave. people walking down Bickford ave to catch the bus often cross street at this point This location is a good candidate for a crosswalk
Impossible to see oncoming traffic when coming down Bickford ave due to the curve of the road and parked cars. Also, many come up one way street from Heath street

Sidewalk  front St Paul Cath broken  over year  3 '15 I fell on broken sidewalk smashed  face on concrete  Chipped  tooth, got black eye & cut lip, & very deep cut on  knee, & bruises. Called Church but they have not  fixed sidewalk.

All over Boston, drivers run red lights and clip people in crosswalks. This does NOT happen in surrounding cities, such as Cambridge, Brookline, Newton, Dedham. The safety of pedestrians in Boston is on a level with that of Malden, treacherous.

The signage tells cyclists and pedestrians to go right. But when you do, you end up at the top of a high stairway. If you're in a wheelchair or coming back from the grocery store with a heavy shopping cart you are stuck.
Every block there is a double parked car, along with how fast the cars go, it is dangerous to pull into the car lane...need protected bike lane on columbus
vehicles do not stop for pedestrians in cross walk.also, drivers speed. the police would make a fortune by stationing a cop here and fining law breakers.

g street is a residential street.  Commuters use it as a cut through and speed through  it to get to the expressway or morrisey blvd.  it has become much worse since the large trees were removed by the City.

corner of tremont and east berkley the walk sign is so long that everyone jay walks. when you do get the walk sign cars are turning onto berkley st as you are walking and you have to dodge them

Cars often speed at a high rate down W 3rd between E and F
No sidewalk, lots of people commuting to work/BAC creates a dangerous environment

Too many don't use crosswalk.  Dangerous

This is a very dangerous merge - something needs to be done to get people in the right lane on the pike to also yield or some kind of traffic signal when the lane is cleared
Not really a safety concern but the light here is timed very poorly with the Mass Ave / Newbury light and most mornings only 1-2 cars can turn right on a green

The cross of boylston street occurs while cars traveling north on park drive have a green light. Cars frequently turn right onto boylston or honk at pedestrians in the cross walk even though they have the right away
There are not painted lanes or cross walks on much of Tremont Street. As a result, multiple, frequent changes of lane, no path for bicycles, and cross walks not visible

During rush hours, drivers pull up to the rotary and focus on whether or not there is an opening for their vehicle in the rotary. They seem to forget that they have a stop sign and that there are pedestrians in the crosswalk.

People double park here often, and there's frequently 4+ vehicles on this block double parked on both sides of the street making it hard to navigate around them and drive through. It seems that they are often Uber drivers / taxis waiting for fares.

There are often trucks for Domino's and the mattress store double parked here during rush hour. It's frustrating because it eliminates the lane from use and creates a bottle neck of  traffic behind them!
Construction vehicles park here, making it difficult for bus drivers to see me waiting for the bos.
Constantly running red lights, also park where no parking is indicated and also where it says right turn only, they go straight.  Cleary square Hyde Park
Bicyclists do not follow rules of road.  Run red lights.

where there is legal parking only on the east side of Dana because the street is narrow, people often try to park on the west side of the street.  Traffic flow is reduced and, for the E-18 ambulance garaged up the street, is a public safety hazard.

The crosswalks are very far apart, particularly considering the amount of traffic the movie theater and Landmark get, so everyone jaywalks rather than walking all the way over to one of the crosswalks.
Cross walks through Beacon Hill need to be repainted.  Barely visible at this intersection

Many vehicles barely slow down, let alone stop, at this intersection. And there's an elementary school right here!

This is a cut-through street with parking on the west side. The east side is unprotected and has a very narrow sidewalk with a low curb. Many children live on this street, and it is not safe to let them walk on the sidewalk due to speeding cars.
There is not enough room on the road for bikes and a two way street, very dangerous for bikers, drivers and pedestrians
Vehicles turn onto Dorchester St. from 1st st. and then SPEED up to Broadway, since there are no stop signs.

column7: but especially motorcycles and dirt bikes from the area that also go the WRONG way on this one-way street

People constantly speed on this street!

this may also qualify as not having enough time to cross the street. people turning from W. Newton to Columbus ignore the people crossing Columbus as they turn, even if the walk signal indicates that it's time to walk.

There should be a sidewalk between the arch bridge to the Arboretum so that people with stroller, bikes and wheelchairs can enter the Arboretum safely.

Hyde Park T is a haven for drunks and druggies. The sidewalks on the River St and Business St sides dont get plowed in winter due to a jurisdictional dispute between the city and the railroad. The Business St/River St sidewalks need resurfacing.

Sleeper st should be turned into one-way to allow for wider sidewalks.  Tiny and unsafe sidewalks and it's next to children's museum! The sidewalk along the museum is not a sidewalk - barely a foot wide. Unsafe!

People going North on Dartmouth St. turning left onto Newbury get a green light at the same time pedestrians get a walk signal. Because the drivers turning left have a green light they don't seem to realize the pedestrians have the right of way.
Uber drivers on weekends double park all over this area for the bars here. It creates gridlock for drivers which can back up the columbus/dartmouth intersection.

Drivers turning left onto Berkley from Columbus have a green when pedestrians have a walk signal. They never seem to expect pedestrians and don't stop for them. I've almost been hit here several times by clueless drivers.

Very dangerous for pedestrians.  Drivers turning onto Sleeper do not have enough visibility to notice pedestrians and right next to children's museum with many kids walking around, sleeper should be made one-way street
Very dangerous street for a cut through.  Many people speed from congress to Seaport blvd, would recommend speed bumps and wider sidewalks

Drivers often run the light here and get stuck blocking the box on Dartmouth once pedrians start crossing. They then get honked at which leads to them trying to squeeze through gaps in pedestrian traffic.

\There should be an \"\"all of the above\"\" for this one. One of the worst intersections for a pedestrian in the city. The 4 way stop here is a welcomed improvement. But I still see someone nearly get hit here everyday.\""

This whole intersection is a disaster & will only get worse since there is a giant building being erected here. There are several streets meeting, unconventionally. T's confusing to know the direction someone is traveling.
very high foot traffic crosswalk cars do not stop to let people cross the street

There is an ongoing issue with people cutting through from Columbia rd. Up Jerome at high speeds and a high volume of traffic . it is very dangerous  for the people and children who live and walk on this Street.

In the morning hours especially between 7:10-8am

This is a crosswalk used by high schoolers every single day and drivers jump the light and speed through the intersection regularly.  I have yelled at drivers many times over the past two decades; I worry for the safety of our students.

column7: you are required to make a \"\"Dorchester Left\"\"--pulling into traffic to see oncoming traffic--in order to make a turn.\""

One way street people use as cut through and speed

and fail to yield at the crosswalk, which is not on a signal. more often than not, no one stops.

High traffic public park, lots of children. No sidewalk and people speed around the corner.
Forest Hills st here is wide enough to paint a bike lane. it would help cars keep to the left and leave bikes plenty of space to labor up this hill.

Why is there no indication to cyclists the the bike path continues if you turn left here? This is one of those things you're just supposed to know?? Much safer for cyclists to turn left here rather than up at the Mass Ave intersection!

Please put bike specific signal here and re-time the lights to give more parity between bikes/cars (or more priority to bikes!) The wait is too long for bikes trying to continue N on the SW corridor (Columbus bike lane)

There is no way to get back from Copley to the SW Corridor without either taking your life into your hands or going against traffic or going on the sidewalk. I'd like to be able to get BACK from the Farmers' Market without getting killed!
People speed.  There is increased traffic due to work at Forest Hills.  There are loud motorcycles that often go the wrong direction on the road.
There is increased traffic here due to construction at Forest Hills.  It needs a light because right now there is too much traffic for safe moves.  It has become a Lord of the Flies situation.

kids  can't play in front of the houses or ride a bike because the speed of the cars its to dangers,, and sometimes have  accident  between greenwood and fowlers st because its not a stop sign no where.

no way to request walk sign at many busy pedestrian intersections on columbus ave from centre to washington

Drivers use this road to cut through WR, JP, and avoid traffic jams and they treat the street like if it was a huge main road so sometimes cars are going as fast as 50-65mph causing many accidents including pets, children, and pedestrians

This area is not safe for bicyclists

This intersection is horrible. There is a blind slip through heading toward Walter where it's extremely unsafe to cross, plus a right hand turn lane and green arrow coming from south. This is right next to a playground. Sadistic.
This is a fairly sharp curve, and narrow, and people fly through here.
There's either no sidewalk, or very narrow sidewalk with poles in it all along the cemeteries, on both sides. People often walk in the street, dangerous because of poor visibility and speeding cars.

I commute by bike daily on Mass Ave from symphony to Harvard square, and this particular section of the road (spanning the intersection of Boylston and Mass ave to Huntington and Mass ave),  is by far the most dangerous.

I commute by bike daily on Mass Ave from symphony to Harvard square, and this particular section of the road (spanning the intersection of Boylston and Mass ave to Huntington and Mass ave),  is by far the most dangerous.

There are always vehicles parked in the bike lane.
This light takes FOREVER to change to a Walk Light. CONSTANTLY have to wait for the busses to cross street before pedistrians can cross.
drivers consistently speeding and run red lights to get onto the highway ramp. Rush hour is the worst.
There are no crosswalks or other ways to assist pedestrians to cross safely. Drivers speed, visibility is limited, confusing intersection, and large distance for pedestrians to cross safely.
People speed down Centre St., even though there's barely room for cars to pass each other going in either director

Bikers need to transition from the right side to the left side lane, and there is no obvious best way to do this, without simply crossing 3 lanes of traffic
The entire length of the Beacon St. Hill has aweful road conditions.

Eliminating two parking spaces on the south side of Ashmont Street at Dorchester Avenue and creating a right turn lane would ease congestion and reduce aggressive driving by people rushing to get through intersection.

A right turn arrow from Washington St. southbound onto River St. westbound allowing turns at the same time as the existing left turn arrow from River St. to Washington St. northbound would make the intersection safer by easing congestion.
River St. doesn't have a stop sign, but Harvard St. does. But people on Harvard St. often run the stop signs, creating more delays and dangerous situations on River St.

People use Hyde Park Avenue for drag racing because it's a long stretch of road from Forest Hills up to and beyond Cleary Sq.  Now that weather is warmer, bikers on motorcycles and mopeds are also an issue as they race each other.

The intersection of Jamaicaway and Lochstead would benefit greatly from a traffic light.  This would reduce speeding on this part of Jamaicaway and provide a safe means to cross for people to access Jamaica Pond Park.
Almost hit by texting driver flying around corner.  I'm getting really tired of this. People are out of control.
Please remove parking right next to crosswalks. Do a curb out or something. It is really hard to see people in the crosswalks when they're hidden behind an SUV or other large vehicle.
The sidewalk parking occurs on the east side of the street, where no one should be parking.
Crosswalk needed here - tons of people cross here on foot all day long. Dangerous.

When I lived on Mission Hill, biking was safe and easy because of the Southwest Corridor. Now that I live in Dorchester there's nothing for bikers. Riding to work alone Gallivan and Mortin is scary because the cars don't care.
And they speed around the corner and don't yield.  It is a quiet residential street with lots of pedestrians.  Also, lots of bikes chained to signs.
Sidewalks are impassable
Drivers and pedestrians cannot see each other.  Bad signage. And, bicyclists ride on the sidewalks. Capital police says :Not my job.
Too fast for a residential neighborhood.
predatory bicyclists on busy sidewalk, all along Cambridge Street..
Chaos reigns on this corner. Pedestrians can't tell how to get to Bridge.  There have been deaths and many near-misses. We have everything from heavy construction machinery to baby strollers.
Do not stop at corner of W. Cedar. Then they turn right and zoom down to Cambridge.  Don't stop for pedestrians.  Street sign at Camb./ W. Cedar was totaled last year.  Worse in snow.
If one drives speed limit, people will aggressively tailgate and sometimes honk. It's really scary.
Over designed road with excessive speeding
This intersection becomes a nightmare at 5:00 pm every weekday when thousands of commuters cross here because the pedestrian tunnel is closed. Temporarily widen the sidewalks at this intersection!
This is one of the worst spots in the city - cars going straight (west) from Centre to Perkins NEVER stop for pedestrians at this crosswalk. VERY dangerous.
Can't see around the double parked trucks to cross the street.

80% of bicyclists use the sidewalks instead of the bike lanes.  Dangerous to walkers and runners.  The bike lanes could have better markings, different paviings, etc., but the bridge is narrow and we all must share.

There is a metal utility box in the middle of the sidewalk, at the narrowest point of the entire sidewalk where a Bromley-Heath building comes very close to the street. This causes lots of pedestrian conflict..
There is a very narrow sidewalk at this corner, with a stoplight pole right in the middle of it. Very awkward, especially now that the commuter rail pedestrian tunnel is closed.
This corner floods after every rainstorm. Very hard to cross Paul Gore as a pedestrian.
Cars go way too fast on this portion of Boylston Street. Speed calming measures needed.
Crosswalk is too far from stoplight. It's unclear (to both drivers and pedestrians) whether the crosswalk and stoplight are part of the same intersection.
Intersection needs redesign - shorter crosswalk and sidewalk bump-out area maybe?

Stop sign turning right. This slip through should be eliminated. People rarely if ever stop at the stop sign. Very dangerous walking here, especially with my kids when we're trying to get to the playground.
People speed over the bridge to make green light. Maybe the city should discourage cut through traffic.  This bridge should only be used by people who live in the neighborhood.
Disturbing harassing behavior from people driving on Hyde park ave. they speed and will honk and yell at you when on a bike.
columbus is a prime candidate for protected bike lanes. Far too many people double parked here, opening doors into bike lanes, etc...

Some parts of this street are wide enough for parking on both sides, but there is only parking on the west side here. People often park on the sidewalk because the curb is so low. This blocks the path for pedestrians and damages the sidewalk.
People run this stop sign all the time. It would be helpful if a white stop bar were painted on the street to provide an additional visual cue.
People speed and get very close to the sidewalk. Perhaps a shoulder line could be painted about three feet from the curb to keep people away from the curb and in the travel lane.
Intersection is too wide and open so cars speed without considering pedestrians and children in park; no clearly marked crosswalks and no traffic calming measures
School here. Reckless driving next to school
Cars don't care about the pedestrians crossing the street and don't let us cross.
Cars race down Summer Street not yielding to people in the corsswalk even in daylight when plainly seen.  Near misses all the time. No one sees the tiny radar speed sign.
Bike lane between Nashua St and Museum Way would be a GAME CHANGER for outbound cyclists. Please, please please can we have one?

Cars can take a right on red from Lomasney Way onto Staniford Street, and the lights are timed so that they have a red light when we have a crossing sign. There are a lot of patients from MGH and the surrounding doctor's offices who struggle there.
Scary biking through here. People will tailgate and honk.
Need bike facilities here. Lots of kids biking around playground. Speeding cars and dangerous curve. Should be designed for slow speeds, discourage cut through traffic.
The sidewalk along Washington Street has been removed for more than 1 year in this location. Waiting for it to be replaced.

Drivers speed and don't yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk.  When a driver does yield, often other drivers will go around them in the next lane and create a hazard to pedestrians already in the crosswalk.
Crossing Congress by A Street is impossible for pedestrians! There are no stepdowns at the curb for easier access. The lights take too long & give very little time to pedestrians to cross.

Many drivers cut through the neighborhood on morning commute. They come down Rossmore, turn right on Stedman, make an illegal left on Williams, and turn onto Dungarven. They travel at very high speeds. (There is a city playground on Stedman.)

\Heavy pedestrian traffic crossing Thirteenth St and frequent conflicts with vehicle traffic including buses.  The \"\"yield to pedestrians in crosswalks\"\" sign here that belongs in the crosswalk but it keeps getting moved to the side of the road.\""
S-bound traffic on Harrison Ave at Oak St gets both a round green and green arrow signal, peds get do not cross signal on E side of the intersection. Many jaywalk. Please remove green arrow signal.
Lane alignment of Mass Ave across Boylston St really needs to be improved.
Cars often back the wrong way down the street - instead of going around the block. In the past week I have seen three cars go through the intersection the wrong way on Shawmut and union park.
A few bike racks would be great on Shawmut. Lots of small business around here.
There's no yield or stop sign for cars making right turns here
Cars turn left off Shawmut to then go down Milford - which means thy are going in the wrong way - because they don't want to circle around to berkley st.
